attributes.title: Civic Education and Electoral Observation in Violent Elections

q1.value: Civic Education and Electoral Observation in Violent Elections

q2.value: Aila Matanock | Manuela Travaglianti | Justine M. Davis

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Political rivals in many democratizing countries regularly use violence to shape electoral outcomes. This project investigates whether the kind of democracy promotion programs typically supported by foreign donors — civic education and domestic election observation — can influence how citizens experience elections in countries where violence is widely anticipated. What effects do such programs have in such a context? We examine this question in the context of Côte d’Ivoire’s October 2015 election. Multiparty elections in that country have been routinely tainted by violence since a democratic constitution was first enacted in 1990. The October 2015 election we study is the first to be held in Côte d’Ivoire since the previous 2010 presidential election resulted in a low-scale civil war.

q16.value: H1: Participation in civic education should increase voter confidence in the electoral process. H2: Participation in civic education should decrease voter support for parties that use violence. H3: Participation in civic education should decrease voter approval of violent political tactics (e.g., opponent harassment). H4: Participation in civic education should increase voter participation in election activities (e.g., rally attendance, voting). H5: The presence of observers should increase voter confidence in the electoral process. H6: The presence of observers should decrease voter support for parties that use violence. H7: The presence of observers should decrease voter approval of violent political tactics (e.g., opponent harassment). H8: The presence of observers should increase voter participation in election activities (e.g., rally attendance, voting).

q17.value: The project centers on a panel survey that introduces experimental questions alongside standard questions concerning respondents’ trust in the democratic system, confidence in the election, participation in the electoral process, and concerns about violence. The same set of respondents will be interviewed twice: the first interview will occur in the 10 days leading up to the elections, and the second interview will occur after election results have been announced. The first wave of the survey will deliver an experimental treatment that informs randomly selected respondents of either (1) the broad themes promoted during the civic education program, (2) the expected presence of election observers, or (3) a combination of both. Additionally, in Abidjan, the panel survey will enable us to assess whether citizen perceptions vary systematically with exposure to a civic education program conducted in randomly selected neighborhoods. The second wave to be conducted after the elections will repeat many of the same questions posed during the first wave to gauge how respondents’ attitudes may have been influenced by the election result, including the responses of parties. The second wave will also build on the project’s supplementary component, a survey of local election observers. This will provide randomly selected respondents with either positive or negative assessments provided by their local election observers. Since respondents will be asked if they have participated in a civic education program, or have been exposed to its information through others, we will be able to assess whether there are interactive effects between prior exposure to civic education and election observer reports on respondents’ assessment of the election, including their willingness to accept the results even if they were affected by violence.

q27.value: Researchers, Coalition of Civil Society for Peace and Democratic Development (COSOPCI)

attributes.title: Can Politicians Shape Public Attitudes Towards Immigrants?

q1.value: Can Politicians Shape Public Attitudes Towards Immigrants?

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: A large tradition within public opinion research has highlighted the capacity of elites to influence mass public opinion (Zaller 1992). Nevertheless, it is still not well understood precisely how elites might shape public attitudes. Though past research has examined whether elites may activate public opinion through legislative action, there could be other channels such as through their public pronouncements. In this study, I conduct an original survey experiment to assess whether politicians can shape public opinion towards immigrants through their public statements. In addition, it is not known whether these effects decay over time or whether they result in permanent attitudinal shifts among citizens.

q16.value: Survey respondents will be asked to read a brief newspaper article containing a statement regarding immigration, which will be experimentally manipulated to vary its overall sentiment and the author of the statement. There will be four treatments and a control condition: (1) positive statement about immigrants by local resident; (2) positive statement about immigrants by politician; (3) negative statement about immigrants by local resident; (4) negative statement about immigrants by politician; (5) neutral statement about immigrants (control condition). I hypothesize that individuals exposed to negative messages about immigration will adopt a more punitive stance towards immigrants than those who read the positive or neutral statement. Further, I hypothesize that such negative statement will be especially impactful when a politician rather than a local resident says it. In addition, to test whether the effects of politicians’ statements are durable or temporary, half of the sample will be randomly chosen to be re-interviewed two weeks after taking the survey. The other half will be re-interviewed four weeks after initially completing the survey. I hypothesize that the effect of the immigration statement will decline rapidly over time and will no longer be statistically significant two weeks after taking the original survey. I will test whether these immigration statements may have spill over effects and affect respondents’ stated attitudes towards U.S. ethnoracial groups. In line with my previous work, I hypothesize that respondents’ attitudes towards Latinos will harden when they read negative statements about immigration. I expect that no other ethnoracial group will be affected. In addition, I will conduct two tests for interaction effects. More specifically, I will test whether the effects of politicians’ statements are different among older and conservative respondents.

q17.value: The survey experiment will be applied online. The sample will consist of 1400 anonymous US-located individuals above the age of 18 recruited through Amazon’s Mechanical Turk (MTurk) site for a reward of 35 cents each. I expect that about 70 percent of these users will accept to take the survey again (2nd wave). I will test these hypotheses via simple difference in means tests. There will be two main dependent variables: attitudes towards three immigration policies and a feeling thermometer that will gauge respondents’ feelings towards non-Hispanic whites, non-Hispanic blacks, Hispanics, Asians, and Arab-Americans.

q23.value: IRB approval pending, University of Michigan IRB.

attributes.title: What Makes Comforting Difficult for Young Children?

q1.value: What Makes Comforting Difficult for Young Children?

q2.value: Tara A. Karasewich, Sylvia Pinheiro, Nina Buchenrieder, Kristen Dunfield, Valerie A. Kuhlmeier

q3.value:
Past research on prosocial behaviour (i.e., acting to benefit another person) has found that young children do not respond to all types of need with the same readiness. Helping (i.e., responding to an instrumental need, such as picking up a dropped object) often appears earlier in development than comforting (i.e., responding to emotional distress, such as by soothing someone who is injured; Dunfield & Kuhlmeier, 2013; Svetlova, Nichols, & Brownell, 2010). 

Children's prosociality is also influenced by personal factors. Shyness is sometimes found to be a barrier to young children's prosocial behaviour, though its impact varies greatly by the context in which that behaviour is measured (e.g., Karasewich, Kuhlmeier, Beier, & Dunfield, 2019; Schuhmacher, Collard, & Kärtner, 2017).  

The purpose of the present study is to examine different factors that would make comforting a more difficult task than helping for young children, in particular those who are shy.  To do this, we have compared preschool children's performance on four prosocial tasks that varied, in a 2 x 2 design, by type (i.e., helping vs. comforting) and the focus of the prosocial problem (i.e., object vs. social). Changing the focus of the prosocial problem allowed us to vary the level of social engagement required to be prosocial: object-focused tasks allowed children to respond in a less engaged way, by presenting them with an object upon which they could act, while social-focused tasks encouraged children to engage with the person in need more directly.

q4.value:
Original Hypotheses:

1) We expected more children to provide help, overall, than comfort and to be more spontaneous when helping than comforting (i.e., to need fewer cues to act from the experimenter). 

2) We also expected, however, for children be more prosocial and more spontaneously prosocial in object-focused tasks than social-focused tasks. Thus, we expected to find an interaction in performance between the type of prosocial task (helping; comforting) and focus of the prosocial problem (object; social).

3) We expected children who are securely attached to their mothers to be more prosocial, overall, than children who are insecurely attached.  

New Hypotheses:

Because we have already run analyses on the original hypotheses (see explanation in Existing Data) and we found little variance in performance on the helping tasks, the next, unanalyzed, hypotheses are based only on comforting behaviour.

4) We expect children’s prosocial behaviour in the social-focused comforting task (i.e., Hurt Knee) to correlate negatively with their level of shyness (i.e., highly shy children will be less likely to be prosocial in social-focused tasks). In contrast, we do not expect children’s level of shyness and prosocial behaviour in the object-focused comforting task (i.e., Broken Toy) to be related. 

5) When children provide comfort and do so in a verbal manner, we expect shyer children to be ‘object-oriented’ (e.g., suggesting ways the experimenter could fix her broken toy) rather than 'social-oriented' (e.g., telling the experimenter not to cry when she realizes her toy is broken), even when the focus of the prosocial problem is social (i.e., in both the Broken Toy and Hurt Knee tasks).

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value:
The experimenters who interacted with the participants during the study and the research assistants who coded the data from the study videos were all blind to each child's 'shyness' score. 

(Note, however, that we used a within subjects design and so there were no ‘treatments’ – we are interested instead in the effect of the organismic factor 'shyness').

question.value:
We used a within-subjects design for this study. 

While the child’s mother completed the 90-item Attachment Q-Sort (computerized version 2.1.2) lead by a trained research assistant, the experimenter brought the child into the testing room. 

The child was given four prosocial tasks interspersed with four 'delay' games. The prosocial tasks varied, in a 2x2 design, by type (i.e., helping; comforting) and focus of the prosocial problem (i.e., object; social). In helping tasks, the experimenter had a problem in the form of an instrumental need, while in comforting tasks she had a problem in the form of emotional distress. In object-focused prosocial tasks, the child could respond to the helping/comforting problem while focusing on a particular object(s) in the environment, while in the social-focused prosocial tasks, the child would likely have to focus on the experimenter herself when responding to the problem. The four tasks are described in detail below, in the Procedure Outline.

In each prosocial task the child was given up to three cues to respond prosocially, spaced approximately 5 seconds apart for a total of 15 seconds. Cues were given until the child had performed the highest level of a prosocial act for that task (i.e., approaching the experimenter to provide physical comfort in the comforting tasks; physically picking up the target objects in the helping tasks). The order of the prosocial tasks was counterbalanced, such that half of the children received a helping task first (i.e., the Lego task) and half received a comforting task first (i.e., the Hurt Knee task).

Procedure Outline (Order A):

1) Delay Game: Puzzle

At the start of the study, the experimenter and child played the first delay game together - completing a puzzle (of the characters from the TV show "Paw Patrol").

2) Prosocial Task: Hurt Knee (Social-Comforting)

The child was then given the first prosocial task, the Hurt Knee task, in which the experimenter went into an adjoining room to get more toys and then banged her knee on the doorframe while coming back. She said "Ouch," and rubbed her knee while sitting down and then told the child, "Oh, my knee! I banged my knee!" This served as the first of three cues for the child to act. After 5 seconds, a second cue could be given: "Ouch, that really hurts!" The final cue, after 5 more seconds, was, "Is there something you can do?" If the child did not comfort after 15 seconds total, the experimenter solved her own problem: "Oh, I am all better now! I just had to rub it."

3) Delay Game: Tower

Next, the experimenter and child built a tall tower out of Lego Duplo bricks. When the tower was complete, the experimenter put the bricks into a bucket to put them away.

4) Prosocial Task: Lego (Object-Helping)

While walking to the door of the adjacent room to put the Lego bricks away, the experimenter 'accidentally' spilled them onto the floor. She said, "Whoops, I spilled the bricks!" as the first cue for the child to act. After 5 seconds, if the child had not yet responded, the experimenter bent down and picked up two of the bricks then put her arm out to reach for bricks further away, saying "I can't reach them all!" The final cue, after 5 more seconds, was, "Is there something you can do?" If the child did not help after 15 seconds, the experimenter picked up all of the bricks herself, saying "It's okay, I got them." If the child did start to help within those 15 seconds, the experimenter said "Thank you. I should put this [the puzzle] away too!" and left the child to finish picking up the bricks. 

5) Delay Game: Memory

The experimenter then brought out the game Memory to play with the child and explained the rules ("For every card here there is another one that looks the exact same. Every time it's your turn, you can turn around two cards and if they are the same you can keep them!"). The cards that they played with had cartoon animals on their faces, with 10 pairs in total. 

6) Prosocial Task: Broken Toy (Object-Comforting)

At the start of the next prosocial task, the experimenter brought out a toy dog to show the child, which she described as her favourite toy. She played with the toy a bit while telling the child why she liked it (e.g., "I like his floppy ears!"), then stopped when she 'noticed' a rip in the dog's paw. She gasped and said, "Oh no! My dog! I ripped my doggy!" as the first cue for the child to act. She immediately put the toy down on the table (within reach of the child) and covered her face with her hands. She did not touch or interact with the toy again until the task ended. After 5 seconds, she could give the second cue, “Oh no, I'm really sad!" and the final cue, "Is there something you can do?" was given 5 seconds after that. If 15 seconds passed without the child making a prosocial response, or if the child did respond prosocially in a way that would not immediately solve the experimenter's problem (e.g., suggesting that they ask the child's mother to sew the rip), the experimenter 'realized', "Oh, we can just push the stuffing back inside! See, it's all better now!"

7) Delay Game: Tic-Tac-Toe

The experimenter then brought out a magnetic tic-tac-toe game to play with the child and explained the rules ("It goes like this: each player tries to put his 3 symbols in a row, either from top to bottom, side to side, or across"). They played 2-3 rounds of tic-tac-toe. 
 
8) Prosocial Task: Sticker (Social-Helping)

At the start of the final prosocial task, the experimenter went to get a jacket from the adjacent room because, "[she was] a little chilly." She put the jacket, which had a square post-it note sticker stuck to the back (in between the shoulder blades), on in the adjacent room before coming back to the testing room. The experimenter then went to reach for a pen behind the table when she 'realized', "Whoops, I think I have something on my back!" This line, and the experimenter trying to reach for the sticker, served as the first cue for the child to act. If the child had not taken the sticker off within 5 seconds, the experimenter said "I can't reach it!" After 5 more seconds, she could give the final cue, "Is there something you can do?" If the child did not respond within 15 seconds, the experimenter said, "It's okay, I got it!", pulled the jacket to bring the sticker within reach, and took it off.  

9) Free Play

The experimenter and the child then played with toys in the adjacent room until the research assistant indicated that the child's mother had completed the Q-Sort, by knocking on the testing room door. The child was then encouraged to pick out a small prize from a toy box to thank them for participating.  

The counterbalanced Order B followed the same procedure described above, but in the following order:

1 (Puzzle -- Delay) 
3 (Tower -- Delay)
4 (Lego -- Object-Helping)
5 (Memory -- Delay)
2 (Hurt Knee -- Social-Comforting)
7 (Tic-Tac-Toe -- Delay)
8 (Sticker -- Social-Helping)
6 (Broken Toy -- Object-Comforting)
9 (Free Play)

q10.value: Registration following analysis of the data

q11.value:
Data was originally collected and analyzed for an honour's thesis project (with Nina Buchenrieder as Principal Investigator) in the fall of 2015 and winter of 2016. Since then, we have become interested in the impact that shyness has on young children's prosocial behaviour and have decided to add shyness coding and analysis to this project.

The main research questions of the original thesis study were:

1) Are children more likely to help than to comfort? Will children help more spontaneously than they comfort (i.e., respond with fewer cues)?

2) Are children more likely to be prosocial and to act more spontaneously when the prosocial problem is object-focused rather than social-focused? 

3) Are children who show secure attachment to their mothers more likely to be prosocial than children with insecure attachment?

These questions have already been analyzed, in completion of the honour's thesis:

1) We have calculated the frequency of children's helping/comforting behaviour in the four tasks, the type of response made, and the number of cues required for each child to act.

2) We have compared the number of cues needed for a prosocial response across the four tasks (using repeated-measures ANOVA and Bonferroni corrected post-hoc analysis) 

3) We have computed security of attachment scores for each child in the sample and found a restricted range with a skewed distribution (i.e., most of the sample was securely attached to their mothers). Because of this restricted range, we will not be analyzing attachment security any further in the project.  

In planning the next analyses for this project (i.e., incorporating shyness), we have also taken the following steps:

1) Two trained coders have rated each child's 'social engagement' on a three-point scale (very engaged/not shy = 2; moderately engaged/shy = 1; not engaged/very shy = 0) during two 'delay' games (i.e., puzzle and tic-tac-toe) as one possible measure of shyness. Because interrater agreement for this measure was moderate, though somewhat low (e.g., Cohen’s Kappa = .64 for the puzzle game) and we felt that a continuous measure would provide more information about children's level of shyness than a 3-point categorization, we decided to drop this measure from the analyses. 

2) We have created a shyness subscale from the attachment Q-sort, by identifying items that describe shy behaviours, checking internal consistency of the scale, and removing two items that had only moderate correlation with the others. We have already analyzed how shyness as reported by parents relates to the measures of prosocial performance that were calculated for the original thesis (i.e., did they help/comfort; what type of response did they make; how many cues did they need to act). 

3) We have had research assistants transcribe the experimenter's and children's speech during the first delay game (puzzle) in order to code their speech behaviour as an additional measure of shyness.  We have not performed any major analyses using these data, but we have checked interrater agreement and found it to be moderately good (Cohen’s Kappa = 0.705). Because this measure was added post-hoc and we had two individuals act as the experimenter for approximately half of the sample (23 and 19, respectively), we also checked whether they were equal in how much they spoke to each child, on average. Thus, we calculated the number of utterances made by the experimenter during the puzzle game for each child, divided that number by the time (in seconds) that they spent playing the game, and conducted an independent t-test comparing the speech behaviour of the two experimenters. Although the difference we found in the experimenters’ speech was not statistically significant (t(40) = 1.784, p = .082), we feel that it is large enough to merit caution in interpreting this, post-hoc, measure. We will thus be considering children’s speech behaviour as an exploratory measure of shyness, only.

4) We have also had research assistants transcribe the experimenter's and children's speech during the two comforting tasks (Hurt Knee; Broken Toy). Two trained research assistants coded the type of verbal comforting children provided to the experimenter (i.e., object vs. social) during both comforting tasks. We have not performed any analyses using these data.

question.value: Participating families were recruited at community events in a small city in Ontario, Canada. Children were given a small toy to thank them for participating. Children were considered eligible for the study if they were between the ages of 3.5 to 4.5 years old at the test date. Mothers completed the Attachment Q-Sort for their children. Data was collected in the fall of 2015 and winter of 2016.

q13.value:
The final sample size (already collected) is 42 children and their mothers. 

51 children were tested initially and 9 were excluded due to experimenter error (4), equipment failure (1), and participant factors (4).

q14.value:
Because we decided to test the relation between shyness and children’s prosocial behaviour in this study after the data was already collected for different hypotheses, we have conducted a post-hoc power analysis (in G*Power 3.1.9.2; Faul, Enfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) to assess whether our sample size is adequate for our new hypotheses. 

In the post-hoc power analysis, alpha was set to 0.05 and we used our sample size of 42. The effect size was set to .36 based on a comparable prior study, which assessed preschool children’s comforting behaviour and shyness within the same lab session (Young, Fox, & Zahn-Waxler, 1999). Power was calculated to be 0.79, which we consider adequate.

question.value: N/A

1) Performance on the prosocial tasks

a) Type of Response

We have recorded whether children acted prosocially in each of the four tasks and what type of response they made.


Prosocial Responses:

- Lego (Object-Helping)

A child could be prosocial in the Lego task by physically helping the experimenter. Physical help would involve picking up any of the bricks and handing them to the experimenter, moving the bricks closer to her, or putting bricks in the bucket. 

- Sticker (Social-Helping)

A child could be prosocial in the Sticker task by physically or verbally helping the experimenter. Physical help would involve taking the sticker off of the experimenter’s back, while verbal help would involve telling the experimenter where the sticker was on her back so that she could find it and take it off herself.

- Broken Toy (Object-Comforting)

A child could be prosocial in the Broken Toy task by physically or verbally comforting the experimenter. Physical comfort would involve hugging the experimenter or attempting to fix the broken toy. Verbal comfort would involve saying something to try to soothe her distress (e.g., telling her “It’s okay” or “Don’t cry”), offering physical comfort (e.g., “Do you want a hug?”), or suggesting a solution to the broken toy (e.g., telling her how to fix/cover up the rip or suggesting she get a new toy). 

- Hurt Knee (Social-Comforting)

A child could be prosocial in the Hurt Knee task by physically or verbally comforting the experimenter. Physical comfort would involve hugging the experimenter or kissing/rubbing her injured knee. Verbal comfort would involve saying something to try to soothe her distress (e.g., telling her “It’s okay” or “Don’t cry”), offering physical comfort (e.g., “Do you want a hug?”), or suggesting a way to heal her injury (e.g., suggesting they get a band-aid or ice). 


Other Responses:

We have categorized non-prosocial responses as either ‘no response’ or an ‘empty verbal response'. 

- No Response

A child was recorded as making ‘no response’ if they said nothing during the task and did not make any physical attempt to be prosocial.

- Empty Verbal Response 

A child was recorded as making an ‘empty verbal response’ if they spoke during the task, but did not try to address the experimenter’s prosocial problem (e.g., if the child ignored the situation: “Can we play another game?”). 


b) Verbal Comforting Orientation

We have had two trained coders assess children’s verbal comforting in the Broken Toy and Hurt Knee tasks to determine whether each response was object-oriented or social-oriented. 

Although children could make multiple comforting statements, of either or both types, during a single period, we are most interested in whether shyness interferes with children’s use of ‘social-oriented’ comforting strategies. Thus, we will be categorizing participants’ verbal comforting as ‘social-oriented’ if they provide any verbal comforting response that is social in nature and ‘object-oriented’ if they provide only verbal comforting responses that involve an object. That is, if a child provides a single social-oriented verbal comforting response they will be categorized as ‘social-oriented’ even if they have provided multiple other comforting responses that were ‘object-oriented’, because the social response takes priority in our scoring. 

- Object-Oriented 

Verbal comforting is considered ‘object-oriented’ when it is focused on an object relevant to the situation. For example, the child may suggest ways that the experimenter could fix her broken toy dog (focused on the toy itself) or offer to get a band-aid for her hurt knee (focused on a band-aid). 

- Social-Oriented 

Verbal comforting is considered ‘social-oriented’ when it is focused on the experimenter’s feelings. For example, the child may try to soothe her, in either comforting task, by saying “It’s okay” or “Don’t cry” or by offering physical comfort (e.g., “Do you want a hug?”).  


c) Spontaneity of Prosocial Response

We have recorded how spontaneously children acted in each of the four prosocial tasks as the number of cues (1-3) needed for the child to make their first prosocial response (if they made one). 

In all four prosocial tasks the first cue was a basic statement of the experimenter’s problem, the second cue was a more specific statement of the problem, and the third cue asked the child directly whether they could intervene. Thus, when a child was ‘most spontaneous’ in being prosocial, this means that they required only a basic statement to intervene, while a child who was ‘least spontaneous’ required a more direct request. 

List of Cues:

Lego (OH)
1. “Whoops, I spilled the bricks!”
2. “I can’t reach them all!”
3. “Is there something you can do?”

Sticker (SH)
1. “Whoops, I think I have something on my back!”
2. “I can’t reach it!”
3. “Is there something you can do?”

Broken Toy (OC)
1. “Oh no! My dog! I ripped my doggy!”
2. “Oh no, I’m really sad!”
3. “Is there something you can do?”

Hurt Knee (SC)
1. “Oh, my knee! I banged my knee!”
2. “Ouch, that really hurts!”
3. “Is there something you can do?”


2) Shyness

We have created a shyness subscale from the Attachment Q-Sort (computerized version 2.1.2, which uses the same items as the paper version 3), which was completed by the children’s mothers, by following the procedure described by Waters at this webpage: http://www.psychology.sunysb.edu/attachment/measures/content/aqs_method.html

We began by identifying items that we felt described shy behaviours – 14 in total from the original 90 items. We then checked the internal consistency of this subscale and the correlations between each item using the already completed responses from the mothers in our sample. 

Two items were removed from the subscale for being only moderately related to the other items:

1. Child becomes shy or loses interest when an activity looks like it might be difficult
2. When given a choice child would rather play with toys than with adults

The final subscale has 12 items:

1. When he is upset or injured, child will accept comforting from adults other than mother (R)
2. Child is more interested in people than in things (R)
3. Child laughs and smiles easily with a lot of different people (R)
4. Child quickly gets used to people or things that initially made him shy or frightened him (R)
5. Child is willing to talk to new people, show them toys, or show them what he can do, if mother asks him to (R)
6. Child readily lets new adults hold or share things he has, if they ask to (R)
7. Child runs to mother with a shy smile when new people visit the home
8. Child’s initial reaction when people visit the home is to ignore or avoid them, even if he eventually warms up to them
9. Child largely ignores adults who visit the home. Finds his own activities more interesting
10. Child easily grows fond of adults who visit his home and are friendly to him (R)
11. When the family has visitors, child wants them to pay a lot of attention to him (R)
12. Child enjoys being hugged or held by people other than his parents and/or grandparents (R) 

Scores on the final 12 items will be summed (with the identified items (R) reverse-coded) to obtain a mother-reported shyness score for each child.
N/A

Original Hypotheses (already analyzed):

1-2) Children in our sample would help more than comfort and would be more prosocial in object-focused tasks than in social-focused tasks

a) Did children act? (Frequency) 

- Lego (OH): 42/42 helped 

- Sticker (SH): 40/42 helped

- Broken Toy (OC): 31/42 comforted 

- Hurt Knee (SC): 18/42 comforted 


b) What types of responses did they make? (Frequency) 

- Lego (OH): 42 helped physically 

- Sticker (SH): 39 helped physically, 1 helped verbally, and 2 gave an empty verbal response

- Broken Toy (OC): Of the 31 children who comforted, 6 only comforted physically by trying to fix the toy, 22 only comforted verbally, and 3 did both. Of the children who did not comfort, 8 gave an empty verbal response and 3 made no response. 

- Hurt Knee (SC): 6 comforted physically by approaching the experimenter (e.g., kissing her knee), 12 comforted verbally, 12 gave an empty verbal response, and 12 made no response.


c) How spontaneously was their prosocial behaviour? (Frequency and ANOVA)

- Lego (OH): 26 helped after the 1st cue, 15 helped after the 2nd, and 1 helped after the 3rd

- Sticker (SH): 21 helped after the 1st cue, 14 helped after the 2nd, 5 helped after the 3rd, and 2 did not help

- Broken Toy (OC): 18 comforted after the 1st cue, 7 comforted after the 2nd, 6 comforted after the 3rd, and 11 did not comfort

- Hurt Knee (SC): 7 comforted after the 1st cue, 2 comforted after the 2nd, 9 comforted after the 3rd, and 24 did not comfort

To compare the spontaneity of prosocial behaviour across the four tasks, we’ve conducted a one-way repeated measures ANOVA including only those children who were prosocial in all four tasks (n = 17). A significant difference in spontaneity was found: F(2.291, 36.658) = 6.570, p = .003 (Greenhouse-Geisser method). Pairwise comparisons using the Bonferroni correction found significant differences in spontaneity between the Sticker (SH) and Hurt Knee (SC) tasks (p = .018) and between the Lego (OH) and Hurt Knee (SC) tasks (p = .010). 


3) Securely attached children would be more prosocial

Attachment scores in our sample ranged from .20 to .66, with a mean of .47 and standard deviation of .11. This is a very restricted range of scores, given that scores on the Q-Sort can range from -1 (most insecurely attached) to +1 (most securely attached). Thus, our sample primarily consisted of securely attached children and we do not feel that we can make meaningful inferences about the role that attachment plays in young children’s prosociality from our data. 


New Hypotheses (partially analyzed):

4) Children’s level of shyness will relate negatively to their comforting in the Hurt Knee (social-focused) task, but will not relate to their comforting in the Broken Toy (object-focused) task

a) Does shyness predict which children comforted in each task? (Logistic regressions)

We have run two analyses examining whether children’s scores on the Q-Sort shyness subscale (IV) predicted whether or not they comforted (DV) in the Broken Toy (OC) and Hurt Knee (SC) tasks, respectively. Neither analysis was significant. 

b) Does shyness predict whether children approached the experimenter when comforting? (Logistic Regression)

We have run one analysis examining whether children’s scores on the Q-Sort shyness subscale (IV) predict whether or not they approached the experimenter when comforting (DV) in the Hurt Knee (SC) task. (No child approached the experimenter in the Broken Toy task). This analysis was not significant.

c) Does shyness relate to how spontaneously children comforted? (Correlations)

We have run two analyses to examine whether children’s scores on the Q-Sort shyness subscale related to the number of cues required for them to respond in the Broken Toy (OC) and Hurt Knee (SC) tasks, respectively. We found no relation in the Hurt Knee task (r = -.218, p = .385) and only a marginal negative relation in the Broken Toy task (r = -.341, p = .060), suggesting that shyer children tended to require more cues to comfort the experimenter after she broke her toy.

5) Shyer children will be less likely to be 'social-oriented’ (as opposed to ‘object-oriented’) when providing verbal comfort (in either task)

a) Does shyness predict whether children were social-oriented when providing verbal comfort? (Logistic Regressions)

We will conduct two analyses to examine whether children’s scores on the Q-Sort shyness subscale (IV) predict whether or not they provided social-oriented verbal comforting (DV) in the Broken Toy (OC) and Hurt Knee (SC) tasks, respectively.

A child will be considered an outlier if their standardized shyness score on the Q-Sort-shy scale or from their speech during the puzzle game falls beyond the cut-off of +/- 3.29 (Tabachnick & Fidell, 2013). We will account for outliers, if needed, by truncating our data.

In comparing the spontaneity of prosocial responses across the four tasks, we excluded all of the children who did not act prosocially in all tasks (i.e., 25 children were excluded).

In examining if shyness predicted whether children who comforted approached the experimenter in the Hurt Knee task, we excluded children who did not provide any form of comfort in that task (i.e., 24 children were excluded).

In examining the relation between shyness and how spontaneously children comforted in the Broken Toy and Hurt Knee tasks, we excluded children who did not provide any form of comfort in each task (i.e., 24 children were excluded in the Hurt Knee task and 11 were excluded in the Broken Toy task). 

When examining the relation between shyness and the types of verbal comforting children may provide in the Broken Toy and Hurt Knee tasks, those who did not provide verbal comforting (i.e., children who only comforted physically or did not make any comforting response) will be excluded.

q24.value:
As an exploratory measure of children’s shyness toward the experimenter, we will code children’s speech during the puzzle delay game. We have chosen to focus only on the puzzle game because it was significantly longer than most of the other delay games (average time of puzzle: 6.15 minutes; tower: 1.68 minutes, tic-tac-toe: 1.61 minutes), which would have given the experimenter and child time to have a conversation. The memory game was of similar length to the puzzle (average time of memory: 4.56 minutes), but the transcribers noted that the majority of utterances that children made when playing the memory game were merely labelling the animals they saw on the cards (e.g., “A cow”; “Polar bear and a goose”). 

Research assistants transcribed all of the experimenter and child’s utterances during this period and two trained coders have used these transcriptions to categorize each child’s speech, one utterance at a time, into three main types: 

1. Responsive (i.e., the child was following the experimenter’s lead with their next utterance)

2. Initiating (i.e., the child moved the conversation in a new direction, though it may still be within the same broad topic as the experimenter’s last utterance)

3. Irrelevant (i.e., the child’s utterance contained only a gesture, self-talk, or thinking sounds, or had been marked in the transcription process as being unclear because of poor audio quality, the child muttering, etc.)

A behavioural shyness score for the puzzle game will be calculated for each child by adding up the number of responsive utterances that the child made, dividing by their total number of utterances (i.e., responsive and initiating; irrelevant utterances will be excluded from this total), and multiplying that value by 100. Thus, we will have a score for each child that represents the percentage of their speech behaviour in which they merely responded to the experimenter’s attempts at conversation, rather than taking initiative, themselves.

We will conduct two analyses to examine if children’s scores on the speech during the puzzle game measure (IV) predict whether or not they provided social-oriented verbal comforting (DV) in the Broken Toy (OC) and Hurt Knee (SC) tasks, respectively.

registration_responses.q1: What Makes Comforting Difficult for Young Children?
registration_responses.q2: Tara A. Karasewich, Sylvia Pinheiro, Nina Buchenrieder, Kristen Dunfield, Valerie A. Kuhlmeier
registration_responses.q3:
Past research on prosocial behaviour (i.e., acting to benefit another person) has found that young children do not respond to all types of need with the same readiness. Helping (i.e., responding to an instrumental need, such as picking up a dropped object) often appears earlier in development than comforting (i.e., responding to emotional distress, such as by soothing someone who is injured; Dunfield & Kuhlmeier, 2013; Svetlova, Nichols, & Brownell, 2010). 

Children's prosociality is also influenced by personal factors. Shyness is sometimes found to be a barrier to young children's prosocial behaviour, though its impact varies greatly by the context in which that behaviour is measured (e.g., Karasewich, Kuhlmeier, Beier, & Dunfield, 2019; Schuhmacher, Collard, & Kärtner, 2017).  

The purpose of the present study is to examine different factors that would make comforting a more difficult task than helping for young children, in particular those who are shy.  To do this, we have compared preschool children's performance on four prosocial tasks that varied, in a 2 x 2 design, by type (i.e., helping vs. comforting) and the focus of the prosocial problem (i.e., object vs. social). Changing the focus of the prosocial problem allowed us to vary the level of social engagement required to be prosocial: object-focused tasks allowed children to respond in a less engaged way, by presenting them with an object upon which they could act, while social-focused tasks encouraged children to engage with the person in need more directly.
registration_responses.q4:
Original Hypotheses:

1) We expected more children to provide help, overall, than comfort and to be more spontaneous when helping than comforting (i.e., to need fewer cues to act from the experimenter). 

2) We also expected, however, for children be more prosocial and more spontaneously prosocial in object-focused tasks than social-focused tasks. Thus, we expected to find an interaction in performance between the type of prosocial task (helping; comforting) and focus of the prosocial problem (object; social).

3) We expected children who are securely attached to their mothers to be more prosocial, overall, than children who are insecurely attached.  

New Hypotheses:

Because we have already run analyses on the original hypotheses (see explanation in Existing Data) and we found little variance in performance on the helping tasks, the next, unanalyzed, hypotheses are based only on comforting behaviour.

4) We expect children’s prosocial behaviour in the social-focused comforting task (i.e., Hurt Knee) to correlate negatively with their level of shyness (i.e., highly shy children will be less likely to be prosocial in social-focused tasks). In contrast, we do not expect children’s level of shyness and prosocial behaviour in the object-focused comforting task (i.e., Broken Toy) to be related. 

5) When children provide comfort and do so in a verbal manner, we expect shyer children to be ‘object-oriented’ (e.g., suggesting ways the experimenter could fix her broken toy) rather than 'social-oriented' (e.g., telling the experimenter not to cry when she realizes her toy is broken), even when the focus of the prosocial problem is social (i.e., in both the Broken Toy and Hurt Knee tasks).
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)
registration_responses.q7:
The experimenters who interacted with the participants during the study and the research assistants who coded the data from the study videos were all blind to each child's 'shyness' score. 

(Note, however, that we used a within subjects design and so there were no ‘treatments’ – we are interested instead in the effect of the organismic factor 'shyness').
registration_responses.q10: Registration following analysis of the data
registration_responses.q11:
Data was originally collected and analyzed for an honour's thesis project (with Nina Buchenrieder as Principal Investigator) in the fall of 2015 and winter of 2016. Since then, we have become interested in the impact that shyness has on young children's prosocial behaviour and have decided to add shyness coding and analysis to this project.

The main research questions of the original thesis study were:

1) Are children more likely to help than to comfort? Will children help more spontaneously than they comfort (i.e., respond with fewer cues)?

2) Are children more likely to be prosocial and to act more spontaneously when the prosocial problem is object-focused rather than social-focused? 

3) Are children who show secure attachment to their mothers more likely to be prosocial than children with insecure attachment?

These questions have already been analyzed, in completion of the honour's thesis:

1) We have calculated the frequency of children's helping/comforting behaviour in the four tasks, the type of response made, and the number of cues required for each child to act.

2) We have compared the number of cues needed for a prosocial response across the four tasks (using repeated-measures ANOVA and Bonferroni corrected post-hoc analysis) 

3) We have computed security of attachment scores for each child in the sample and found a restricted range with a skewed distribution (i.e., most of the sample was securely attached to their mothers). Because of this restricted range, we will not be analyzing attachment security any further in the project.  

In planning the next analyses for this project (i.e., incorporating shyness), we have also taken the following steps:

1) Two trained coders have rated each child's 'social engagement' on a three-point scale (very engaged/not shy = 2; moderately engaged/shy = 1; not engaged/very shy = 0) during two 'delay' games (i.e., puzzle and tic-tac-toe) as one possible measure of shyness. Because interrater agreement for this measure was moderate, though somewhat low (e.g., Cohen’s Kappa = .64 for the puzzle game) and we felt that a continuous measure would provide more information about children's level of shyness than a 3-point categorization, we decided to drop this measure from the analyses. 

2) We have created a shyness subscale from the attachment Q-sort, by identifying items that describe shy behaviours, checking internal consistency of the scale, and removing two items that had only moderate correlation with the others. We have already analyzed how shyness as reported by parents relates to the measures of prosocial performance that were calculated for the original thesis (i.e., did they help/comfort; what type of response did they make; how many cues did they need to act). 

3) We have had research assistants transcribe the experimenter's and children's speech during the first delay game (puzzle) in order to code their speech behaviour as an additional measure of shyness.  We have not performed any major analyses using these data, but we have checked interrater agreement and found it to be moderately good (Cohen’s Kappa = 0.705). Because this measure was added post-hoc and we had two individuals act as the experimenter for approximately half of the sample (23 and 19, respectively), we also checked whether they were equal in how much they spoke to each child, on average. Thus, we calculated the number of utterances made by the experimenter during the puzzle game for each child, divided that number by the time (in seconds) that they spent playing the game, and conducted an independent t-test comparing the speech behaviour of the two experimenters. Although the difference we found in the experimenters’ speech was not statistically significant (t(40) = 1.784, p = .082), we feel that it is large enough to merit caution in interpreting this, post-hoc, measure. We will thus be considering children’s speech behaviour as an exploratory measure of shyness, only.

4) We have also had research assistants transcribe the experimenter's and children's speech during the two comforting tasks (Hurt Knee; Broken Toy). Two trained research assistants coded the type of verbal comforting children provided to the experimenter (i.e., object vs. social) during both comforting tasks. We have not performed any analyses using these data.
registration_responses.q13:
The final sample size (already collected) is 42 children and their mothers. 

51 children were tested initially and 9 were excluded due to experimenter error (4), equipment failure (1), and participant factors (4).
registration_responses.q14:
Because we decided to test the relation between shyness and children’s prosocial behaviour in this study after the data was already collected for different hypotheses, we have conducted a post-hoc power analysis (in G*Power 3.1.9.2; Faul, Enfelder, Lang, & Buchner, 2007) to assess whether our sample size is adequate for our new hypotheses. 

In the post-hoc power analysis, alpha was set to 0.05 and we used our sample size of 42. The effect size was set to .36 based on a comparable prior study, which assessed preschool children’s comforting behaviour and shyness within the same lab session (Young, Fox, & Zahn-Waxler, 1999). Power was calculated to be 0.79, which we consider adequate.

registration_responses.q8.question:
We used a within-subjects design for this study. 

While the child’s mother completed the 90-item Attachment Q-Sort (computerized version 2.1.2) lead by a trained research assistant, the experimenter brought the child into the testing room. 

The child was given four prosocial tasks interspersed with four 'delay' games. The prosocial tasks varied, in a 2x2 design, by type (i.e., helping; comforting) and focus of the prosocial problem (i.e., object; social). In helping tasks, the experimenter had a problem in the form of an instrumental need, while in comforting tasks she had a problem in the form of emotional distress. In object-focused prosocial tasks, the child could respond to the helping/comforting problem while focusing on a particular object(s) in the environment, while in the social-focused prosocial tasks, the child would likely have to focus on the experimenter herself when responding to the problem. The four tasks are described in detail below, in the Procedure Outline.

In each prosocial task the child was given up to three cues to respond prosocially, spaced approximately 5 seconds apart for a total of 15 seconds. Cues were given until the child had performed the highest level of a prosocial act for that task (i.e., approaching the experimenter to provide physical comfort in the comforting tasks; physically picking up the target objects in the helping tasks). The order of the prosocial tasks was counterbalanced, such that half of the children received a helping task first (i.e., the Lego task) and half received a comforting task first (i.e., the Hurt Knee task).

Procedure Outline (Order A):

1) Delay Game: Puzzle

At the start of the study, the experimenter and child played the first delay game together - completing a puzzle (of the characters from the TV show "Paw Patrol").

2) Prosocial Task: Hurt Knee (Social-Comforting)

The child was then given the first prosocial task, the Hurt Knee task, in which the experimenter went into an adjoining room to get more toys and then banged her knee on the doorframe while coming back. She said "Ouch," and rubbed her knee while sitting down and then told the child, "Oh, my knee! I banged my knee!" This served as the first of three cues for the child to act. After 5 seconds, a second cue could be given: "Ouch, that really hurts!" The final cue, after 5 more seconds, was, "Is there something you can do?" If the child did not comfort after 15 seconds total, the experimenter solved her own problem: "Oh, I am all better now! I just had to rub it."

3) Delay Game: Tower

Next, the experimenter and child built a tall tower out of Lego Duplo bricks. When the tower was complete, the experimenter put the bricks into a bucket to put them away.

4) Prosocial Task: Lego (Object-Helping)

While walking to the door of the adjacent room to put the Lego bricks away, the experimenter 'accidentally' spilled them onto the floor. She said, "Whoops, I spilled the bricks!" as the first cue for the child to act. After 5 seconds, if the child had not yet responded, the experimenter bent down and picked up two of the bricks then put her arm out to reach for bricks further away, saying "I can't reach them all!" The final cue, after 5 more seconds, was, "Is there something you can do?" If the child did not help after 15 seconds, the experimenter picked up all of the bricks herself, saying "It's okay, I got them." If the child did start to help within those 15 seconds, the experimenter said "Thank you. I should put this [the puzzle] away too!" and left the child to finish picking up the bricks. 

5) Delay Game: Memory

The experimenter then brought out the game Memory to play with the child and explained the rules ("For every card here there is another one that looks the exact same. Every time it's your turn, you can turn around two cards and if they are the same you can keep them!"). The cards that they played with had cartoon animals on their faces, with 10 pairs in total. 

6) Prosocial Task: Broken Toy (Object-Comforting)

At the start of the next prosocial task, the experimenter brought out a toy dog to show the child, which she described as her favourite toy. She played with the toy a bit while telling the child why she liked it (e.g., "I like his floppy ears!"), then stopped when she 'noticed' a rip in the dog's paw. She gasped and said, "Oh no! My dog! I ripped my doggy!" as the first cue for the child to act. She immediately put the toy down on the table (within reach of the child) and covered her face with her hands. She did not touch or interact with the toy again until the task ended. After 5 seconds, she could give the second cue, “Oh no, I'm really sad!" and the final cue, "Is there something you can do?" was given 5 seconds after that. If 15 seconds passed without the child making a prosocial response, or if the child did respond prosocially in a way that would not immediately solve the experimenter's problem (e.g., suggesting that they ask the child's mother to sew the rip), the experimenter 'realized', "Oh, we can just push the stuffing back inside! See, it's all better now!"

7) Delay Game: Tic-Tac-Toe

The experimenter then brought out a magnetic tic-tac-toe game to play with the child and explained the rules ("It goes like this: each player tries to put his 3 symbols in a row, either from top to bottom, side to side, or across"). They played 2-3 rounds of tic-tac-toe. 
 
8) Prosocial Task: Sticker (Social-Helping)

At the start of the final prosocial task, the experimenter went to get a jacket from the adjacent room because, "[she was] a little chilly." She put the jacket, which had a square post-it note sticker stuck to the back (in between the shoulder blades), on in the adjacent room before coming back to the testing room. The experimenter then went to reach for a pen behind the table when she 'realized', "Whoops, I think I have something on my back!" This line, and the experimenter trying to reach for the sticker, served as the first cue for the child to act. If the child had not taken the sticker off within 5 seconds, the experimenter said "I can't reach it!" After 5 more seconds, she could give the final cue, "Is there something you can do?" If the child did not respond within 15 seconds, the experimenter said, "It's okay, I got it!", pulled the jacket to bring the sticker within reach, and took it off.  

9) Free Play

The experimenter and the child then played with toys in the adjacent room until the research assistant indicated that the child's mother had completed the Q-Sort, by knocking on the testing room door. The child was then encouraged to pick out a small prize from a toy box to thank them for participating.  

The counterbalanced Order B followed the same procedure described above, but in the following order:

1 (Puzzle -- Delay) 
3 (Tower -- Delay)
4 (Lego -- Object-Helping)
5 (Memory -- Delay)
2 (Hurt Knee -- Social-Comforting)
7 (Tic-Tac-Toe -- Delay)
8 (Sticker -- Social-Helping)
6 (Broken Toy -- Object-Comforting)
9 (Free Play)
registration_responses.q12.question: Participating families were recruited at community events in a small city in Ontario, Canada. Children were given a small toy to thank them for participating. Children were considered eligible for the study if they were between the ages of 3.5 to 4.5 years old at the test date. Mothers completed the Attachment Q-Sort for their children. Data was collected in the fall of 2015 and winter of 2016.
registration_responses.q16.question: N/A
registration_responses.q17.question:
1) Performance on the prosocial tasks

a) Type of Response

We have recorded whether children acted prosocially in each of the four tasks and what type of response they made.


Prosocial Responses:

- Lego (Object-Helping)

A child could be prosocial in the Lego task by physically helping the experimenter. Physical help would involve picking up any of the bricks and handing them to the experimenter, moving the bricks closer to her, or putting bricks in the bucket. 

- Sticker (Social-Helping)

A child could be prosocial in the Sticker task by physically or verbally helping the experimenter. Physical help would involve taking the sticker off of the experimenter’s back, while verbal help would involve telling the experimenter where the sticker was on her back so that she could find it and take it off herself.

- Broken Toy (Object-Comforting)

A child could be prosocial in the Broken Toy task by physically or verbally comforting the experimenter. Physical comfort would involve hugging the experimenter or attempting to fix the broken toy. Verbal comfort would involve saying something to try to soothe her distress (e.g., telling her “It’s okay” or “Don’t cry”), offering physical comfort (e.g., “Do you want a hug?”), or suggesting a solution to the broken toy (e.g., telling her how to fix/cover up the rip or suggesting she get a new toy). 

- Hurt Knee (Social-Comforting)

A child could be prosocial in the Hurt Knee task by physically or verbally comforting the experimenter. Physical comfort would involve hugging the experimenter or kissing/rubbing her injured knee. Verbal comfort would involve saying something to try to soothe her distress (e.g., telling her “It’s okay” or “Don’t cry”), offering physical comfort (e.g., “Do you want a hug?”), or suggesting a way to heal her injury (e.g., suggesting they get a band-aid or ice). 


Other Responses:

We have categorized non-prosocial responses as either ‘no response’ or an ‘empty verbal response'. 

- No Response

A child was recorded as making ‘no response’ if they said nothing during the task and did not make any physical attempt to be prosocial.

- Empty Verbal Response 

A child was recorded as making an ‘empty verbal response’ if they spoke during the task, but did not try to address the experimenter’s prosocial problem (e.g., if the child ignored the situation: “Can we play another game?”). 


b) Verbal Comforting Orientation

We have had two trained coders assess children’s verbal comforting in the Broken Toy and Hurt Knee tasks to determine whether each response was object-oriented or social-oriented. 

Although children could make multiple comforting statements, of either or both types, during a single period, we are most interested in whether shyness interferes with children’s use of ‘social-oriented’ comforting strategies. Thus, we will be categorizing participants’ verbal comforting as ‘social-oriented’ if they provide any verbal comforting response that is social in nature and ‘object-oriented’ if they provide only verbal comforting responses that involve an object. That is, if a child provides a single social-oriented verbal comforting response they will be categorized as ‘social-oriented’ even if they have provided multiple other comforting responses that were ‘object-oriented’, because the social response takes priority in our scoring. 

- Object-Oriented 

Verbal comforting is considered ‘object-oriented’ when it is focused on an object relevant to the situation. For example, the child may suggest ways that the experimenter could fix her broken toy dog (focused on the toy itself) or offer to get a band-aid for her hurt knee (focused on a band-aid). 

- Social-Oriented 

Verbal comforting is considered ‘social-oriented’ when it is focused on the experimenter’s feelings. For example, the child may try to soothe her, in either comforting task, by saying “It’s okay” or “Don’t cry” or by offering physical comfort (e.g., “Do you want a hug?”).  


c) Spontaneity of Prosocial Response

We have recorded how spontaneously children acted in each of the four prosocial tasks as the number of cues (1-3) needed for the child to make their first prosocial response (if they made one). 

In all four prosocial tasks the first cue was a basic statement of the experimenter’s problem, the second cue was a more specific statement of the problem, and the third cue asked the child directly whether they could intervene. Thus, when a child was ‘most spontaneous’ in being prosocial, this means that they required only a basic statement to intervene, while a child who was ‘least spontaneous’ required a more direct request. 

List of Cues:

Lego (OH)
1. “Whoops, I spilled the bricks!”
2. “I can’t reach them all!”
3. “Is there something you can do?”

Sticker (SH)
1. “Whoops, I think I have something on my back!”
2. “I can’t reach it!”
3. “Is there something you can do?”

Broken Toy (OC)
1. “Oh no! My dog! I ripped my doggy!”
2. “Oh no, I’m really sad!”
3. “Is there something you can do?”

Hurt Knee (SC)
1. “Oh, my knee! I banged my knee!”
2. “Ouch, that really hurts!”
3. “Is there something you can do?”


2) Shyness

We have created a shyness subscale from the Attachment Q-Sort (computerized version 2.1.2, which uses the same items as the paper version 3), which was completed by the children’s mothers, by following the procedure described by Waters at this webpage: http://www.psychology.sunysb.edu/attachment/measures/content/aqs_method.html

We began by identifying items that we felt described shy behaviours – 14 in total from the original 90 items. We then checked the internal consistency of this subscale and the correlations between each item using the already completed responses from the mothers in our sample. 

Two items were removed from the subscale for being only moderately related to the other items:

1. Child becomes shy or loses interest when an activity looks like it might be difficult
2. When given a choice child would rather play with toys than with adults

The final subscale has 12 items:

1. When he is upset or injured, child will accept comforting from adults other than mother (R)
2. Child is more interested in people than in things (R)
3. Child laughs and smiles easily with a lot of different people (R)
4. Child quickly gets used to people or things that initially made him shy or frightened him (R)
5. Child is willing to talk to new people, show them toys, or show them what he can do, if mother asks him to (R)
6. Child readily lets new adults hold or share things he has, if they ask to (R)
7. Child runs to mother with a shy smile when new people visit the home
8. Child’s initial reaction when people visit the home is to ignore or avoid them, even if he eventually warms up to them
9. Child largely ignores adults who visit the home. Finds his own activities more interesting
10. Child easily grows fond of adults who visit his home and are friendly to him (R)
11. When the family has visitors, child wants them to pay a lot of attention to him (R)
12. Child enjoys being hugged or held by people other than his parents and/or grandparents (R) 

Scores on the final 12 items will be summed (with the identified items (R) reverse-coded) to obtain a mother-reported shyness score for each child.
registration_responses.q18.question: N/A
registration_responses.q19.question:
Original Hypotheses (already analyzed):

1-2) Children in our sample would help more than comfort and would be more prosocial in object-focused tasks than in social-focused tasks

a) Did children act? (Frequency) 

- Lego (OH): 42/42 helped 

- Sticker (SH): 40/42 helped

- Broken Toy (OC): 31/42 comforted 

- Hurt Knee (SC): 18/42 comforted 


b) What types of responses did they make? (Frequency) 

- Lego (OH): 42 helped physically 

- Sticker (SH): 39 helped physically, 1 helped verbally, and 2 gave an empty verbal response

- Broken Toy (OC): Of the 31 children who comforted, 6 only comforted physically by trying to fix the toy, 22 only comforted verbally, and 3 did both. Of the children who did not comfort, 8 gave an empty verbal response and 3 made no response. 

- Hurt Knee (SC): 6 comforted physically by approaching the experimenter (e.g., kissing her knee), 12 comforted verbally, 12 gave an empty verbal response, and 12 made no response.


c) How spontaneously was their prosocial behaviour? (Frequency and ANOVA)

- Lego (OH): 26 helped after the 1st cue, 15 helped after the 2nd, and 1 helped after the 3rd

- Sticker (SH): 21 helped after the 1st cue, 14 helped after the 2nd, 5 helped after the 3rd, and 2 did not help

- Broken Toy (OC): 18 comforted after the 1st cue, 7 comforted after the 2nd, 6 comforted after the 3rd, and 11 did not comfort

- Hurt Knee (SC): 7 comforted after the 1st cue, 2 comforted after the 2nd, 9 comforted after the 3rd, and 24 did not comfort

To compare the spontaneity of prosocial behaviour across the four tasks, we’ve conducted a one-way repeated measures ANOVA including only those children who were prosocial in all four tasks (n = 17). A significant difference in spontaneity was found: F(2.291, 36.658) = 6.570, p = .003 (Greenhouse-Geisser method). Pairwise comparisons using the Bonferroni correction found significant differences in spontaneity between the Sticker (SH) and Hurt Knee (SC) tasks (p = .018) and between the Lego (OH) and Hurt Knee (SC) tasks (p = .010). 


3) Securely attached children would be more prosocial

Attachment scores in our sample ranged from .20 to .66, with a mean of .47 and standard deviation of .11. This is a very restricted range of scores, given that scores on the Q-Sort can range from -1 (most insecurely attached) to +1 (most securely attached). Thus, our sample primarily consisted of securely attached children and we do not feel that we can make meaningful inferences about the role that attachment plays in young children’s prosociality from our data. 


New Hypotheses (partially analyzed):

4) Children’s level of shyness will relate negatively to their comforting in the Hurt Knee (social-focused) task, but will not relate to their comforting in the Broken Toy (object-focused) task

a) Does shyness predict which children comforted in each task? (Logistic regressions)

We have run two analyses examining whether children’s scores on the Q-Sort shyness subscale (IV) predicted whether or not they comforted (DV) in the Broken Toy (OC) and Hurt Knee (SC) tasks, respectively. Neither analysis was significant. 

b) Does shyness predict whether children approached the experimenter when comforting? (Logistic Regression)

We have run one analysis examining whether children’s scores on the Q-Sort shyness subscale (IV) predict whether or not they approached the experimenter when comforting (DV) in the Hurt Knee (SC) task. (No child approached the experimenter in the Broken Toy task). This analysis was not significant.

c) Does shyness relate to how spontaneously children comforted? (Correlations)

We have run two analyses to examine whether children’s scores on the Q-Sort shyness subscale related to the number of cues required for them to respond in the Broken Toy (OC) and Hurt Knee (SC) tasks, respectively. We found no relation in the Hurt Knee task (r = -.218, p = .385) and only a marginal negative relation in the Broken Toy task (r = -.341, p = .060), suggesting that shyer children tended to require more cues to comfort the experimenter after she broke her toy.

5) Shyer children will be less likely to be 'social-oriented’ (as opposed to ‘object-oriented’) when providing verbal comfort (in either task)

a) Does shyness predict whether children were social-oriented when providing verbal comfort? (Logistic Regressions)

We will conduct two analyses to examine whether children’s scores on the Q-Sort shyness subscale (IV) predict whether or not they provided social-oriented verbal comforting (DV) in the Broken Toy (OC) and Hurt Knee (SC) tasks, respectively.

attributes.title: Using event-related potentials to capture automatic associations of exercise related images

data.value: No, no data have been collected for this study yet.

name.value: Using event-related potentials to capture automatic associations of exercise related images.

other.value:
Physical activity images will consist of three types to help distinguish between mode of physical activity (group-based, individual/dyad, and outdoor). Therefore, a secondary analysis using a 2 (Group: like, dislike) x 3 (Activity mode: group-based, individual/dyad, and outdoor) mixed factor ANOVA will be conducted for both LPP mean amplitudes. Additionally, a 2 (Group: active, insufficiently active) x 3 (Activity mode: group-based, individual/dyad, and outdoor) mixed factor ANOVA will be conducted for LPP mean amplitudes.
We may also conduct linear mixed effect regressions wherein stimuli are treated as a random factor.

sample.value: We will collect data from approximately 70 participants (35 who like physical activity and 35 who dislike physical activity). This N was selected based on similar experiments previously conducted and an a priori power calculation using G*Power 3.1. Similar to previous pre-registered studies, partial eta square = 0.09 assuming an alpha = .05. With power set to 80% the calculation yielded N = 62, but 70 will be collected to account for poor EEG recording.

analyses.value:
(1) Mean differences in LPP amplitudes will be analyzed using a 2 (Group: like, dislike) x 4 (Image Type: exercise, positive, negative, neutral) mixed-factor ANOVA with repeated-measures on the second factor. We predict a significant group x image type interaction, which will be followed with independent-sample t-tests between groups for the exercise-related images. Similarly, a 2 (Group: active, insufficiently active) x 4 (Image Type: exercise, positive, negative, neutral) mixed-Factor ANOVA with repeated-measures will be conducted to compare LPP amplitudes among active vs. insufficiently active and follow-up analyses will be conducted to examine differences in LPP between image types.

(2) P3b amplitude analysis will follow a similar pattern. A 2 (Group: like, dislike) x 3 (Context: positive, negative, neutral) and a 2 (Group: active, insufficiently active) x 3 (Context: positive, negative, neutral) mixed-factor ANOVA with repeated-measures will be conducted. A significant interaction between group (preference) and context, and between group (activity level) and context is predicted, which will be followed with independent-sample t-tests between groups for the exercise-related images.

outliers.value: All subjects with history of medical, cardiovascular, neurological, psychiatric disorders (clinical depression, ADHD, anxiety), or a head injury that resulted in loss of consciousness will be excluded from participation in the study.

dependent.value:
Motivated attentional processing and automatic affective evaluations of exercise-related images will be measured using the amplitudes of the LPP and P3b components, respectively.                                                                                                                                       

(1) LPP amplitudes will be assessed using time-locked ERPs to exercise-related images compared to positive, negative, and neutral IAPS images. Using a collapsed localizer approach (precise time window to be determined), LPP amplitudes will be quantified based on a mean voltage between 400-1,000 ms post-stimulus at centroparietal midline electrode sites, unless LPP exhibits an unexpected latency or scalp distribution. Greater LPP amplitudes elicited by exercise-related images relative to neutral images will suggest greater motivated attentional processing towards the exercise-related images, suggesting that these images are being processed as motivationally relevant. Similar LPP amplitudes to neutral and exercise-related images will suggest equally motivated attentional processing to exercise-related and neutral images. Differences in LPP amplitudes will be compared between individuals with different preferential views (liking vs. disliking) toward physical activity and exercise. 

(2) Time-locked ERPs to the onset of exercise-related images in an image classification task (Miller et al., under review) will be used to index changes in the P3b component. Exercise-related images will be examined within the context of positive, negative, and neutral IAPS image blocks and the P3b will be used to index the potential for context updating. Using a collapsed localizers approach (precise time window to be determined), the time window for the P3b will be centered on the mean voltage between 300 and 800 ms at centroparietal midline electrode sites, unless P3b exhibits an unexpected latency or scalp distribution.

conditions.value: Based on responses to the physical activity enjoyment scale (PACES), participants will be separated into two groups: (1) individuals who self-report a liking of physical activity as indicated by a score in the top 25th percentile on the PACES, and (2) individuals who self-report a disliking of physical activity, as indicated by the bottom 25th percentile on the PACES. Responses to the Godin Leisure-Time Exercise Questionnaire (LTEQ) will also be used to separate the sample into two groups, active and insufficiently active.

hypothesis.value:
Do people with different preferential views toward physical activity and exercise (i.e. liking vs disliking of physical activity and exercise) exhibit different neural responses to exercise-related images relative to positive, negative, and neutral images from the International Affective Picture System (IAPS). Specifically, the late positive potential (LPP) and P3b event-related potential (ERP) components elicited by exercise-related images will be compared between individuals who differ in their expressed liking of physical activity. 

        Hypothesis 1: It is hypothesized that individuals who report liking exercise (top 25th percentile on the PACES) will evidence larger LPP amplitudes to exercise-related images compared to individuals who self-report disliking exercise (bottom 25th percentile on the PACES).

        Hypothesis 2: It is hypothesized that those who like physical activity and are sufficiently active will exhibit smaller P3b amplitudes to exercise-related images presented within a positive relative to a negative context. Participants who dislike physical activity and are insufficiently active are predicted to exhibit smaller P3b amplitudes to exercise-related images presented within a negative compared to positive context (Miller et al., under review).
