attributes.title: Structural Stigma, Amygdala Reactivity to Threat, and Hippocampal Volume:  A Longitudinal Study of Four Groups

q1.value: Structural Stigma, Amygdala Reactivity to Threat, and Hippocampal Volume:  A Longitudinal Study of Four Groups

q3.value:
There is a robust literature linking experiences of stigma (and the related constructs of prejudice, discrimination, and bias) to adverse outcomes across the life course and across a range of diverse groups, including racial and ethnic minorities, sexual and gender minorities, immigrants, and women (e.g., Clark et al., 1999; Hatzenbuehler, 2009; Major & O’Brien, 2005; Pascoe & Smart Richman, 2009). Because of its pervasiveness, its disruption of multiple life domains, and its corrosive impact on the health of populations, researchers have argued that stigma represents a “fundamental cause” of population health inequalities (Hatzenbuehler, Phelan, & Link, 2013). 

One of the central ideas to emerge from this literature is that stigma exists at multiple levels of analysis (Link & Phelan, 2001; Major, Link, & Dovidio, 2017)—ranging from individual responses (e.g., self-stigma) and interpersonal events (e.g., discriminatory treatment) to structural factors (e.g., social policies, institutional practices). While most social science research has focused on the consequences of individual and interpersonal forms of stigma for the stigmatized, over the past decade a new line of research has emerged illustrating that structural forms of stigma, defined as “societal-level conditions, cultural norms, and institutional policies and practices that constrain the opportunities, resources, and wellbeing of the stigmatized” (Hatzenbuehler & Link, 2014, p. 2), also adversely shape the lives of the stigmatized. The deleterious consequences of structural stigma have been established across a range of: (a) health outcomes, including psychiatric morbidity, suicide attempts, health behaviors, and all-cause mortality; (b) measures of structural stigma, such as state-level policies and aggregated community norms; (c) stigmatized groups, including sexual minorities, African Americans, and immigrants; and (d) methodological approaches, including observational, quasi-experimental, and laboratory designs (see Hatzenbuehler, 2016; 2017 for reviews). 

While this literature has established that structural stigma is a risk indicator for poor health, the mechanisms underlying this association have received less empirical attention. One set of mechanisms that researchers have begun to evaluate involve stress pathways—encompassing perceptions of stress and the regulation of neurobiological systems that govern stress responses. Preliminary evidence for a stress-related pathway comes from both indirect and direct tests. In terms of indirect tests, in one quasi-experimental study researchers obtained data from medical billing records in a community-based health clinic in Massachusetts to examine associations between the passage of the state’s same-sex marriage law and health care use and costs among sexual minority men. Substantial reductions in several stress-related disorders—including a 14% reduction in depression and an 18% reduction in hypertension—were observed in the 12 months after the legalization of same-sex marriage compared to the 12 months before, providing suggestive evidence for a stress pathway (Hatzenbuehler, O'Cleirigh, et al., 2012). In another quasi-experimental study, Lauderdale (2006) used birth certificate data to compare birth rates in the 6 months after September 11th, 2001 with the same 6 calendar months one year before September 11th. The relative risk of poor birth outcomes, including low birth weight, was statistically significantly elevated in the 6 months after September 11th for Arabic-named women but not for White, Black, Hispanic, Asian/Pacific Islander, or Native American women. Given the large literature linking stress to pre-term birth (for a discussion, see Lauderdale, 2006), this study provides additional indirect evidence for a stress pathway linking structural stigma to health.   

In terms of direct tests, research has suggested that structural stigma may be associated with physiological stress responses. For instance, in a lab-based study, researchers recruited 74 LGB young adults who were raised in 24 states as adolescents. These states differed substantially in terms of the level of structural stigma, which was coded based on a composite measure that included state policies and social attitudes. All respondents, who were currently living in New York (a low structural stigma state), completed a well-validated laboratory stressor, the Trier Social Stress Test (TSST). Neuroendocrine measures were collected before, during, and after the TSST. LGB young adults who grew up in high structural stigma states (compared to low structural stigma states) evidenced a blunted cortisol response following the TSST (Hatzenbuehler & McLaughlin, 2014). This same pattern of hypocortisolism has been documented in other samples exposed to chronic life stressors, such as among youth experiencing childhood maltreatment (Gunnar, Frenn, Wewerka, & Van Ryzin, 2009). 

These results provide preliminary evidence for a stress-related pathway linking structural stigma and health.  Here, we extend this work to examine whether structural stigma leads to changes in the structure and function of brain regions that are influenced by experiences of stress and play a central role in regulation stress responses; specifically, the amygdala and hippocampus. The current study addresses this question by using recently-released data from the ABCD study. Specifically, drawing on prior literature, we will develop state-level indicators of structural stigma/discrimination related to sexual orientation (Hatzenbuehler, 2016), race (Lukachko, Hatzenbuehler, & Keyes, 2013), gender (Homan, 2019), and Hispanic ethnicity (Hatzenbuehler, Prins, Flake, Philbin, Frazer, Hagen, & Hirsch, 2017). We will then link these indicators to the ABCD dataset via the FIPS code of the state where the ABCD study site is located to determine their association with two neural measures that are associated with exposure to psychosocial stressors: hippocampal volume (Hanson et al., 2015; McLaughlin et al., 2016; McLaughlin, Weissman, & Bitrán, 2019; Saxbe et al., 2018) and amygdala reactivity to threat (Hein & Monk, 2017; McCrory et al., 2011; McLaughlin, Peverill, Gold, Alves, & Sheridan, 2015). In addition, we will examine associations between individual forms of stigma (i.e., perceived discrimination) and these same two neural outcomes. This will be the first study, to our knowledge, to use a multi-level approach to the study of stigma and neurobiological development. Collectively, this research has the potential not only to advance our understanding of mechanisms linking structural stigma to adverse outcomes, but also to build an evidence base for an emerging subfield of environmental neuroscience (Berman, Stier, & Akcelik, 2019). 

Study Hypotheses    

Our study hypotheses described below are informed by developmental research on identity awareness, formation, and responsivity to identity-based stressors. This research indicates that our four groups develop their identities at different ages, and thus are likely to be aware of, and respond to, structural forms of stigma at different points across development. Below, we briefly review evidence for these developmental differences across the four groups included in our study. 

Sexual orientation. A population-based survey of 1,154 LGBT adults were asked the following three questions about developmental milestones for sexual minority identities (Pew Research Center, 2013): 1) How old were you when you first thought you were something other than straight or heterosexual? 2) How old were you when you knew for sure you were LGBT? 3) How old were you when you first told a close friend or family member that you were LGBT? The median age at which respondents first thought they were something other than straight or heterosexual was 12; it was 17 when they first knew for sure that they were LGBT and 20 when they first told a close friend or family member that they were LGBT. 

Sex/Gender. The literature on gender identity development shows that gender learning occurs early and is a gradual process throughout childhood and adolescence (Steensma et al., 2013). While children develop an awareness of their gender by age three (Collier et al., 2013; La Freniere et al., 1984), gender constancy—the understanding that gender is a fixed personal attribute with distinct expectations for boys and girls—develops later, around age six to seven (Grusec, 2011). By this age (age 6-7), girls have already internalized the societal attitude that girls/women are inferior in intelligence and capability (Brown & Stone, 2016). For example, in their review of 4 studies (N = 400 children), Bian and colleagues (2017) found that by age 6 and 7, girls are less likely than boys to believe that members of their gender are “really, really smart.” By the end of childhood (age 11-12), girls report being less content with their gender than boys (Egan & Perry, 2001; Steensma et al., 2013). By the time young women finish high school, they report experiencing both subtle and overt discrimination, which can lead to lower confidence and motivation (Brown & Stone, 2016). 

Latinx ethnicity. Latinx ethnic identity development emerges during early childhood (Bernal, Knight, Garza, Ocampo, & Cota, 1990; Serrano-Villar & Calzada, 2016) and continues through adolescence (Umaña‐Taylor, Gonzales‐Backen, & Guimond, 2009).  Serrano-Villar and Clazada (2016) explored ethnic identity formation during early childhood among a sample of Mexican American and Dominican American children enrolled in Pre-K or Kindergarten (N=674 families; Mage = 58 months, SD=6.92) living in the United States.  Participants answered questions related to ethnic self-identification (i.e., “Are you a Mexican/Dominican boy/girl or Chinese boy/girl?”), constancy of identity (i.e., “When you grow up, will you be a Mexican/Dominican man/woman or a Chinese man/woman?”), and ethnic knowledge (i.e., “What does it mean to be Mexican/Dominican?”). Results showed that 75% of children self-identified as Mexican or Dominican, 56.8% demonstrated an understanding of constancy in identity, and 21.8% demonstrated knowledge about their ethnic identity.  In a comparatively older sample of Mexican-American children, 6 to 10 years old, Bernal and colleagues (1990) found that 85.7% of children 6 to 8 years of age, and 95.8% of children 8 to 10 years of age, correctly identified his or her ethnicity.  Further, a majority of the 8-to-10-year-old children were able to provide clear and accurate reasons as to why they identified as Mexican and, compared to the 6-to-8-year-old children, demonstrated a greater and nearly complete understanding of identity permanence.  According to Bernal and colleagues (1990), “…it appears that the ability to label the ethnic group to which they belong reaches asymptote sometime before 7 or 8 years of age” (p.20). Given that ethnic identity development emerges during childhood, it is perhaps expected that during this same time period Latino youth will begin to perceive/experience ethnic-based discrimination.  Among a Mexican-origin Latino sample of 1,374 5th grade students (9 to 13 years of age; 96% 10 to 11 years of age) living in Phoenix, Arizona, 59% perceived some ethnic discrimination (Kulis, Marsigilia, & Nieri, 2009). The Health and Growth of Puerto Rican Children Study found lower rates of perceived discrimination among a sample of Puerto Rican children living in the greater Boston area in grades 1 to 3 (Mage= 8.37).  Among this sample, 13% reported being treated badly because of being Puerto Rican (Szalacha, Erkut, Coll, Alarcon, Fields, & Ceder, 2003).  However, in a second study, the Puerto Rican Adolescent Study, the same authors found that among 248 Puerto Rican adolescents ages 13-14 years of age, 49% reported experiencing ethnic discrimination in at least one of nine possible situations (e.g., “when you were with classmates”; Szalacha, Erkut, Coll, Alarcon, Fields, & Ceder, 2003).  Collectively, these studies suggest that among Latino youth, perceptions of discrimination begin during early childhood (e.g., 7-9 years of age) and increase with age.

Race. Much like ethnicity, the development of racial identity emerges during early childhood and continues through adolescence. Children are able to correctly identify their racial identity between ages 3-6; however, children also demonstrate “an awareness of the value attached to whiteness” during this time (Fishbein 2002). For instance, studies consistently find that some racial minority preschoolers and elementary students misidentify themselves as white up until around age seven (Boocock and Scott 2005; DeCuir-Gunby 2009). By age 7-8, children can comprehend both social and physical dimensions of race and recognize some flexibility in racial categorization (e.g., multiracial status) (Alejandro-Wright, 1985). By age 10-12, children understand racial constancy and demonstrate a more “adult-like” understanding of the social construction of race (Alejandro-Wright 1985; Byrd 2012; DeCuir-Gunby 2009). In a review of 70 studies on racial/ethnic identity, Phinney (1990) points out that although children understand race as a concept, an “achieved” racial identity is not complete until late adolescence or early adulthood when individuals move from an unexamined ethnic/racial identity through a period of exploration to an achieved or committed identity. 
	Importantly, during childhood and adolescence individuals begin moving beyond their immediate family environments, encountering societal institutions that are often covertly and overtly racist (Sellers et al 2006). In their study of 277 urban children and adolescents (age 8-16), Pachter and colleagues (2010) found that 88% of participants reported one or more experiences with racial discrimination. Rates of discriminatory treatment are particularly high among African American children and adolescents. In a 5-year study of 714 Black children (ages 10-12), for instance, 92% reported experiencing racial discrimination in the past year (Brody et. al 2006). A growing body of research also shows that membership in a racial minority group is a central reason for bullying and other forms of peer victimization in school settings (Seaton et al 2013). Overall, these findings suggest that similar to ethnicity, self-reported experiences of racial discrimination begin in childhood and increase with age.

q4.value:
Hypothesis #1 (baseline). We predict that greater exposure to structural forms of stigma of one’s identity (measured at the state level) will be associated with smaller hippocampal volume and elevated amygdala reactivity to threat cues among members of each of our stigmatized groups defined by sex, sexual orientation, race, and ethnicity, controlling for demographic characteristics and family SES. 

We further hypothesize that some of these associations will be present at baseline, whereas others will not be present until follow-up waves, given the developmental literature on identity development reviewed above. Specifically, we hypothesize that structural stigma will be associated with smaller hippocampal volume and greater amygdala reactivity to threat at baseline among girls, Latino youth, and African American youth. We do not expect an association among the sexual minority youth until later in adolescence when this identity when more youth begin to identify as lesbian, gay, and bisexual (even if they have not disclosed this identity to others).  

Additionally, we hypothesize that structural forms of stigma will be correlated with individual forms of stigma (i.e., perceived discrimination); that is, respondents will perceive more discrimination based on their sex, race, ethnicity, and sexual orientation in states with relatively high (vs low) levels of structural stigma. In turn, perceived discrimination will be associated with smaller hippocampal volume and elevated amygdala reactivity to threat cues among members of each of our stigmatized groups defined by sex, sexual orientation, race, and ethnicity, controlling for demographic characteristics and family SES. 

Hypothesis #2 (longitudinal). We expect that structural stigma regarding sexual orientation will be associated with smaller hippocampal volume and heightened amygdala reactivity to threat cues among sexual minorities at future time points in ABCD data collection (around age 12-13 years). In addition, identities continue to form during adolescence and structural stigma experiences accumulate during this developmental period. Consequently, we expect the association between structural stigma, smaller hippocampal volume, and greater amygdala reactivity to threat to become stronger over time for all four groups (i.e., the effect size will increase in the longitudinal assessments).   

Hypothesis #3. Structural forms of stigma will not be related to hippocampal volume or amygdala reactivity to threat, either at baseline or longitudinally, among the non-stigmatized comparison groups: boys, heterosexuals, and non-Hispanic Whites. This analysis will serve as a negative control approach (Lipsitch, Tchetgen, & Cohen, 2010), in that we test whether there is an association among groups where we would not theoretically expect it.

Structural stigma will be assessed at the site level for each of the sites of the ABCD study.

question.value:
Independent Variables:
The exposure variables of interest will be state-level structural stigma, relevant to the minority subgroup of interest in each stratified analysis. These are sexual minorities, girls, Latinx, and Black participants. Each of these exposures was compiled from previously-validated sources and then modeled as indicators in a factor analysis, with the final factor score determining the structural stigma score for each state for each domain of stigma. Variable selection and model specification are described here. With the exception of anti-immigrant sentiment (which had a limited inventory of possible indicators), we restricted all indicators to those that had measures for all 50 states and Washington, D.C. The rationale for including all 50 states was to contextualize the factor scores relative to national climate; after models were run using all 50 states, only the states containing ABCD sites will be selected from the larger exposure dataset. See Table 1 for description of final variables. 
Structural Stigma Related to Sex/Gender
Variable selection from General Social Survey 
We selected from eight questions in the General Social Survey (GSS) that had been previously validated as measures of state-level sexism and had been shown to be relatively stable over time (Charles, Guryan, & Pan, 2009; Homan, 2019). These asked about attitudes towards women’s and women’s stereotypical gender roles. Of these, four had been routinely assessed in recent years and were considered for inclusion in the final model.

Variable selection from ANES
We selected from four items in the American National Elections Studies (ANES) Time-Series Survey that assessed attitudes towards stereotypical gender roles and efforts to address women’s rights, gender equality, and gender discrimination.  

Variable selection from Project Implicit
We selected from 16 items included across two Project Implicit Modules assessing sexism within the contexts of careers and science.  The two modules included: 1) The Gender-Career IAT Module; and 2) The Gender-Science IAT Module.  We selected 3 items from The Gender-Career IAT module. These items included an Implicit Association Test assessing the implicit link between gender and a career vs family focus, and two explicit attitude items which assessed gender norms in relation to family and career.  We selected 12 items from the Gender-Science IAT module.  These 12 items included one Implicit Association Test assessing the implicit link between gender and a science vs liberal arts educational focus, and 11 explicit items measuring attitudes, beliefs, and expectations about gendered participation in science, reasons for gender disparities among faculty members in higher education, and gendered performance in STEM fields.
Finally, we examined a series of other state-level measures of sexism based off two seminal papers on structural sexism. These included economic (i.e. labor force participation; earnings; living below poverty line); political (representation; voting rates); autonomy (educational attainment; business ownership; health access; living in poverty); and reproductive (legal and policy protections) indicators. All of these indicators were taken from the McLaughlin et al 2011 and Homan 2019 papers. We used the same sources as those articles to find these state-level data.
Structural racism

Variable selection from GSS
We selected from questions in the General Social Survey that were associated with the subject matter “Blacks” or “race.” Among these, 11 measures were assessed in recent years and queried by respondents in all 50 states plus D.C. 

Variable selection from ANES
We selected from four items included in the American National Elections Studies (ANES) Time-Series Survey that assessed general attitudes towards African Americans, the impact of discrimination on the lives of African Americans, challenges overcoming prejudice, and endorsement of stereotypes.  

Variable selection from Project Implicit
We selected from twenty-five items included in the Project Implicit Race IAT module.  These items included an Implicit Association Test that assessed the implicit positive preference for white versus black faces and twenty-four items that assessed explicit attitudes towards African Americans and endorsement of stereotypes.

We additionally considered the following Black-White disparities as measures of structural racism: Black-White disparities in voter registration, voter turnout, state elected officials, the civilian labor force, employment, employment in executive/managerial positions, professional specialty, college attainment, incarceration, political disenfranchisement, and death sentencing. These have been implicated with racial disparities in cardiovascular outcomes.  We ultimately did not include any of these in our final model as data were unavailable for all 50 states.

Structural stigma related to sexual orientation 
We selected eight variables reflective of sexual minority structural stigma: 1) An index of state laws and policies related to sexual orientation legislated as of 2017. Data were obtained from the Movement Advancement Project; 2) Explicit attitudes held towards homosexuality and the legality of same-sex marriage. Data were obtained from a Pew Research Center for the People & the Press Polls conducted in 2017; 3) Explicit policy-specific support towards laws and policies that impact the rights of LGB people and same-sex couples. Data were obtained from Lax and Phillips (2009), who aggregated results from 41 randomly sampled national public opinion polls, consisting of approximately 80,000 respondents, and conducted from 1999 through 2008 by various organizations (e.g., Gallup, Pew); 4) Implicit attitudes held towards sexual minorities, which were obtained from Project Implicit through which participants voluntarily completed the sexuality version of the Implicit Association Test; 5) A weighted proportion of openly LGBTQ elected government officials. Data were obtained from the Victory Institute’s Out for America interactive map; 6) The proportion of public high schools with Gay-Straight Alliances (GSAs).  Data on GSAs were obtained from the 2016 CDC School Health Profiles; 7) Estimated percentage of LGBT adults living in each state and 8) the estimated density of same-sex couples living in each state.  These data were obtained from the Williams Institute at the UCLA School of Law.


Structural stigma related to Latinx ethnicity
For this domain, very few measures were available for all 50 states plus Washington, D.C., so we excluded Washington, D.C., from the factor analysis. We chose from measures that included explicit attitudinal questions regarding Latinx populations as well as measures related to immigration. As mentioned above, we used measures related to immigration attitudes based on previous findings that immigration policies and attitudes affect the mental health of Latinx respondents regardless of nativity status (e.g., Hatzenbuehler et al., 2017) because of a) the conflation of immigration with Latinx ethnicity in the US, b) the mixed status nature of many Latinx households, and c) the concealability of immigration status, which makes people targets regardless of whether they are a citizen.

Variable selection from GSS
From the General Social Survey, all measures related to the subject “Hispanic” or that appeared using a search for “immigrant” or “immigration” were considered. This consisted of 23 variables; ultimately, only a single one was queried in recent years and had data available for all 50 states. 

Variable selection from ANES
We selected from three items included in the American National Elections Studies (ANES) Times-Series Survey that assessed general attitudes towards Hispanics, attitudes towards illegal immigrants, and endorsement of stereotypes. 

A series of state-level anti-immigrant measures were considered: these were made available by Wake Forest University School of Medicine and provided directly by the project lead, Scott Rhodes. These included state-level policies that were protective or discriminatory towards immigrants; the variable ultimately considered for inclusion from these measures was a sum score for each state representing how supportive or discriminatory the overall laws were, ranging from a score of -6 to +5. These were reverse-coded so that more discriminatory laws had a higher value.

Data cleaning
All measures were coded such that higher levels corresponded to higher values of structural stigma. Measures were standardized to their average response value for all respondents, regardless of state of residence, and aggregated to the state level so that every state’s measure was the mean of the standardized individual response for respondents residing in that state. The exception was state-level variables, which were already measured at the state level and thus were not aggregated or standardized further. Measures met inclusion criteria for model selection if residents of every state and Washington, D.C., were represented in the data. The exception is anti-immigrant sentiment, which heavily relied on measures of state policies; thus, data from Washington, D.C., was not non-existent and so was not included in the models. 
While the indicators often represented different survey years (e.g., General Social Survey questions ranged from the 1970’s to present day), we aggregated all responses to the state level regardless of year queried. Averaging the responses in this way allowed for all states to have a sizable number of representative respondents, regardless of sampling variation from year to year. Structural sexism and structural racism in particular have been shown to decline nationally over time, but the relative stigma levels of individual states (i.e., rankings relative to other states) have remained stable despite national declines overall, so aggregating across multiple years is a commonly accepted technique for assessing structural stigma (Charles et al., 2009; Homan, 2019; McKetta et al., 2017).

Indicator selection into final model
We then created a factor score for each state for each measure by using exploratory factor analysis with a factor loading cut off of 0.40; we reran the factor analysis iteratively and excluded variables until all items in the factor analysis met the 0.40 threshold (n=18 for structural stigma related to sex/gender, n=29 for structural stigma related to race, n=8 for structural stigma related to sexual orientation, and n=4 for structural stigma related to Latinx ethnicity). We performed this analysis using PROC FACTOR in SAS 9.4, with the prior communality estimate fixed at squared multiple correlations with all other variables and oblimin rotation. We considered both a 1-factor and 2-factor solution but chose the 1-factor solution after deeming the 2-factor solution uninterpretable. The variables selected for the final analysis based on the 0.40 loading threshold are included in the attached table. 

Perceived discrimination will be operationalized in two ways: dichotomously and continuously.  

Dichotomous outcomes will be defined as follows:  
Yes on dim_yesno_q1 for race
Yes on dim_yesno_q1 OR dim_yesno_q2 for Latinx ethnicity
Yes on dim_yesno_q3 for sexual orientation

Continuous outcomes will be defined as follows:
The average of dim_matrix_q1 to dim_matrix_q7 for Latinx ethnicity
The average of dim_matrix_q5 to dim_matrix_q7 for race, gender, and sexual orientation

Dependent Variables:
bilateral hippocampal volume, calculated by taking the mean volume across the right and left hemispheres (smri_vol_scs_hpuslh, smri_vol_scs_hpusrh), 
amygdala activation to negative vs. neutral faces, separately for right and left amygdala (tfmri_nback_all_224, tfmri_nback_all_238)

Covariates:
age, sex at birth, marital status of household, household income, race, and ethnicity, total intracranial volume
Analyses will be conducted using generalized mixed-effects models. Subjects are nested within family (sibs) and families nested within site. Implemented using gamm4 function in R.

q21.value: We will use a Bonferroni-corrected p-value of p<.025 to correct for 2 tests on right and left amygdala and a p-value threshold of p<.095 for all other analyses.

q22.value:
All analyses will be conducted within the stigmatized group, with control analyses controlled in the non-stigmatized group.
ABCD guidelines will be followed with regard to exclusion of participants based on data quality, or, for functional scans, based on motion or inattention.

q23.value: We will use multiple imputation to handle missing data of any covariates. As independent variables are at the site level, we don’t expect any missing data there. Each analysis will be restricted through listwise deletion to participants with valid, usable MRI data.

registration_responses.q1: Structural Stigma, Amygdala Reactivity to Threat, and Hippocampal Volume:  A Longitudinal Study of Four Groups
registration_responses.q3:
There is a robust literature linking experiences of stigma (and the related constructs of prejudice, discrimination, and bias) to adverse outcomes across the life course and across a range of diverse groups, including racial and ethnic minorities, sexual and gender minorities, immigrants, and women (e.g., Clark et al., 1999; Hatzenbuehler, 2009; Major & O’Brien, 2005; Pascoe & Smart Richman, 2009). Because of its pervasiveness, its disruption of multiple life domains, and its corrosive impact on the health of populations, researchers have argued that stigma represents a “fundamental cause” of population health inequalities (Hatzenbuehler, Phelan, & Link, 2013). 

One of the central ideas to emerge from this literature is that stigma exists at multiple levels of analysis (Link & Phelan, 2001; Major, Link, & Dovidio, 2017)—ranging from individual responses (e.g., self-stigma) and interpersonal events (e.g., discriminatory treatment) to structural factors (e.g., social policies, institutional practices). While most social science research has focused on the consequences of individual and interpersonal forms of stigma for the stigmatized, over the past decade a new line of research has emerged illustrating that structural forms of stigma, defined as “societal-level conditions, cultural norms, and institutional policies and practices that constrain the opportunities, resources, and wellbeing of the stigmatized” (Hatzenbuehler & Link, 2014, p. 2), also adversely shape the lives of the stigmatized. The deleterious consequences of structural stigma have been established across a range of: (a) health outcomes, including psychiatric morbidity, suicide attempts, health behaviors, and all-cause mortality; (b) measures of structural stigma, such as state-level policies and aggregated community norms; (c) stigmatized groups, including sexual minorities, African Americans, and immigrants; and (d) methodological approaches, including observational, quasi-experimental, and laboratory designs (see Hatzenbuehler, 2016; 2017 for reviews). 

While this literature has established that structural stigma is a risk indicator for poor health, the mechanisms underlying this association have received less empirical attention. One set of mechanisms that researchers have begun to evaluate involve stress pathways—encompassing perceptions of stress and the regulation of neurobiological systems that govern stress responses. Preliminary evidence for a stress-related pathway comes from both indirect and direct tests. In terms of indirect tests, in one quasi-experimental study researchers obtained data from medical billing records in a community-based health clinic in Massachusetts to examine associations between the passage of the state’s same-sex marriage law and health care use and costs among sexual minority men. Substantial reductions in several stress-related disorders—including a 14% reduction in depression and an 18% reduction in hypertension—were observed in the 12 months after the legalization of same-sex marriage compared to the 12 months before, providing suggestive evidence for a stress pathway (Hatzenbuehler, O'Cleirigh, et al., 2012). In another quasi-experimental study, Lauderdale (2006) used birth certificate data to compare birth rates in the 6 months after September 11th, 2001 with the same 6 calendar months one year before September 11th. The relative risk of poor birth outcomes, including low birth weight, was statistically significantly elevated in the 6 months after September 11th for Arabic-named women but not for White, Black, Hispanic, Asian/Pacific Islander, or Native American women. Given the large literature linking stress to pre-term birth (for a discussion, see Lauderdale, 2006), this study provides additional indirect evidence for a stress pathway linking structural stigma to health.   

In terms of direct tests, research has suggested that structural stigma may be associated with physiological stress responses. For instance, in a lab-based study, researchers recruited 74 LGB young adults who were raised in 24 states as adolescents. These states differed substantially in terms of the level of structural stigma, which was coded based on a composite measure that included state policies and social attitudes. All respondents, who were currently living in New York (a low structural stigma state), completed a well-validated laboratory stressor, the Trier Social Stress Test (TSST). Neuroendocrine measures were collected before, during, and after the TSST. LGB young adults who grew up in high structural stigma states (compared to low structural stigma states) evidenced a blunted cortisol response following the TSST (Hatzenbuehler & McLaughlin, 2014). This same pattern of hypocortisolism has been documented in other samples exposed to chronic life stressors, such as among youth experiencing childhood maltreatment (Gunnar, Frenn, Wewerka, & Van Ryzin, 2009). 

These results provide preliminary evidence for a stress-related pathway linking structural stigma and health.  Here, we extend this work to examine whether structural stigma leads to changes in the structure and function of brain regions that are influenced by experiences of stress and play a central role in regulation stress responses; specifically, the amygdala and hippocampus. The current study addresses this question by using recently-released data from the ABCD study. Specifically, drawing on prior literature, we will develop state-level indicators of structural stigma/discrimination related to sexual orientation (Hatzenbuehler, 2016), race (Lukachko, Hatzenbuehler, & Keyes, 2013), gender (Homan, 2019), and Hispanic ethnicity (Hatzenbuehler, Prins, Flake, Philbin, Frazer, Hagen, & Hirsch, 2017). We will then link these indicators to the ABCD dataset via the FIPS code of the state where the ABCD study site is located to determine their association with two neural measures that are associated with exposure to psychosocial stressors: hippocampal volume (Hanson et al., 2015; McLaughlin et al., 2016; McLaughlin, Weissman, & Bitrán, 2019; Saxbe et al., 2018) and amygdala reactivity to threat (Hein & Monk, 2017; McCrory et al., 2011; McLaughlin, Peverill, Gold, Alves, & Sheridan, 2015). In addition, we will examine associations between individual forms of stigma (i.e., perceived discrimination) and these same two neural outcomes. This will be the first study, to our knowledge, to use a multi-level approach to the study of stigma and neurobiological development. Collectively, this research has the potential not only to advance our understanding of mechanisms linking structural stigma to adverse outcomes, but also to build an evidence base for an emerging subfield of environmental neuroscience (Berman, Stier, & Akcelik, 2019). 

Study Hypotheses    

Our study hypotheses described below are informed by developmental research on identity awareness, formation, and responsivity to identity-based stressors. This research indicates that our four groups develop their identities at different ages, and thus are likely to be aware of, and respond to, structural forms of stigma at different points across development. Below, we briefly review evidence for these developmental differences across the four groups included in our study. 

Sexual orientation. A population-based survey of 1,154 LGBT adults were asked the following three questions about developmental milestones for sexual minority identities (Pew Research Center, 2013): 1) How old were you when you first thought you were something other than straight or heterosexual? 2) How old were you when you knew for sure you were LGBT? 3) How old were you when you first told a close friend or family member that you were LGBT? The median age at which respondents first thought they were something other than straight or heterosexual was 12; it was 17 when they first knew for sure that they were LGBT and 20 when they first told a close friend or family member that they were LGBT. 

Sex/Gender. The literature on gender identity development shows that gender learning occurs early and is a gradual process throughout childhood and adolescence (Steensma et al., 2013). While children develop an awareness of their gender by age three (Collier et al., 2013; La Freniere et al., 1984), gender constancy—the understanding that gender is a fixed personal attribute with distinct expectations for boys and girls—develops later, around age six to seven (Grusec, 2011). By this age (age 6-7), girls have already internalized the societal attitude that girls/women are inferior in intelligence and capability (Brown & Stone, 2016). For example, in their review of 4 studies (N = 400 children), Bian and colleagues (2017) found that by age 6 and 7, girls are less likely than boys to believe that members of their gender are “really, really smart.” By the end of childhood (age 11-12), girls report being less content with their gender than boys (Egan & Perry, 2001; Steensma et al., 2013). By the time young women finish high school, they report experiencing both subtle and overt discrimination, which can lead to lower confidence and motivation (Brown & Stone, 2016). 

Latinx ethnicity. Latinx ethnic identity development emerges during early childhood (Bernal, Knight, Garza, Ocampo, & Cota, 1990; Serrano-Villar & Calzada, 2016) and continues through adolescence (Umaña‐Taylor, Gonzales‐Backen, & Guimond, 2009).  Serrano-Villar and Clazada (2016) explored ethnic identity formation during early childhood among a sample of Mexican American and Dominican American children enrolled in Pre-K or Kindergarten (N=674 families; Mage = 58 months, SD=6.92) living in the United States.  Participants answered questions related to ethnic self-identification (i.e., “Are you a Mexican/Dominican boy/girl or Chinese boy/girl?”), constancy of identity (i.e., “When you grow up, will you be a Mexican/Dominican man/woman or a Chinese man/woman?”), and ethnic knowledge (i.e., “What does it mean to be Mexican/Dominican?”). Results showed that 75% of children self-identified as Mexican or Dominican, 56.8% demonstrated an understanding of constancy in identity, and 21.8% demonstrated knowledge about their ethnic identity.  In a comparatively older sample of Mexican-American children, 6 to 10 years old, Bernal and colleagues (1990) found that 85.7% of children 6 to 8 years of age, and 95.8% of children 8 to 10 years of age, correctly identified his or her ethnicity.  Further, a majority of the 8-to-10-year-old children were able to provide clear and accurate reasons as to why they identified as Mexican and, compared to the 6-to-8-year-old children, demonstrated a greater and nearly complete understanding of identity permanence.  According to Bernal and colleagues (1990), “…it appears that the ability to label the ethnic group to which they belong reaches asymptote sometime before 7 or 8 years of age” (p.20). Given that ethnic identity development emerges during childhood, it is perhaps expected that during this same time period Latino youth will begin to perceive/experience ethnic-based discrimination.  Among a Mexican-origin Latino sample of 1,374 5th grade students (9 to 13 years of age; 96% 10 to 11 years of age) living in Phoenix, Arizona, 59% perceived some ethnic discrimination (Kulis, Marsigilia, & Nieri, 2009). The Health and Growth of Puerto Rican Children Study found lower rates of perceived discrimination among a sample of Puerto Rican children living in the greater Boston area in grades 1 to 3 (Mage= 8.37).  Among this sample, 13% reported being treated badly because of being Puerto Rican (Szalacha, Erkut, Coll, Alarcon, Fields, & Ceder, 2003).  However, in a second study, the Puerto Rican Adolescent Study, the same authors found that among 248 Puerto Rican adolescents ages 13-14 years of age, 49% reported experiencing ethnic discrimination in at least one of nine possible situations (e.g., “when you were with classmates”; Szalacha, Erkut, Coll, Alarcon, Fields, & Ceder, 2003).  Collectively, these studies suggest that among Latino youth, perceptions of discrimination begin during early childhood (e.g., 7-9 years of age) and increase with age.

Race. Much like ethnicity, the development of racial identity emerges during early childhood and continues through adolescence. Children are able to correctly identify their racial identity between ages 3-6; however, children also demonstrate “an awareness of the value attached to whiteness” during this time (Fishbein 2002). For instance, studies consistently find that some racial minority preschoolers and elementary students misidentify themselves as white up until around age seven (Boocock and Scott 2005; DeCuir-Gunby 2009). By age 7-8, children can comprehend both social and physical dimensions of race and recognize some flexibility in racial categorization (e.g., multiracial status) (Alejandro-Wright, 1985). By age 10-12, children understand racial constancy and demonstrate a more “adult-like” understanding of the social construction of race (Alejandro-Wright 1985; Byrd 2012; DeCuir-Gunby 2009). In a review of 70 studies on racial/ethnic identity, Phinney (1990) points out that although children understand race as a concept, an “achieved” racial identity is not complete until late adolescence or early adulthood when individuals move from an unexamined ethnic/racial identity through a period of exploration to an achieved or committed identity. 
	Importantly, during childhood and adolescence individuals begin moving beyond their immediate family environments, encountering societal institutions that are often covertly and overtly racist (Sellers et al 2006). In their study of 277 urban children and adolescents (age 8-16), Pachter and colleagues (2010) found that 88% of participants reported one or more experiences with racial discrimination. Rates of discriminatory treatment are particularly high among African American children and adolescents. In a 5-year study of 714 Black children (ages 10-12), for instance, 92% reported experiencing racial discrimination in the past year (Brody et. al 2006). A growing body of research also shows that membership in a racial minority group is a central reason for bullying and other forms of peer victimization in school settings (Seaton et al 2013). Overall, these findings suggest that similar to ethnicity, self-reported experiences of racial discrimination begin in childhood and increase with age.
registration_responses.q4:
Hypothesis #1 (baseline). We predict that greater exposure to structural forms of stigma of one’s identity (measured at the state level) will be associated with smaller hippocampal volume and elevated amygdala reactivity to threat cues among members of each of our stigmatized groups defined by sex, sexual orientation, race, and ethnicity, controlling for demographic characteristics and family SES. 

We further hypothesize that some of these associations will be present at baseline, whereas others will not be present until follow-up waves, given the developmental literature on identity development reviewed above. Specifically, we hypothesize that structural stigma will be associated with smaller hippocampal volume and greater amygdala reactivity to threat at baseline among girls, Latino youth, and African American youth. We do not expect an association among the sexual minority youth until later in adolescence when this identity when more youth begin to identify as lesbian, gay, and bisexual (even if they have not disclosed this identity to others).  

Additionally, we hypothesize that structural forms of stigma will be correlated with individual forms of stigma (i.e., perceived discrimination); that is, respondents will perceive more discrimination based on their sex, race, ethnicity, and sexual orientation in states with relatively high (vs low) levels of structural stigma. In turn, perceived discrimination will be associated with smaller hippocampal volume and elevated amygdala reactivity to threat cues among members of each of our stigmatized groups defined by sex, sexual orientation, race, and ethnicity, controlling for demographic characteristics and family SES. 

Hypothesis #2 (longitudinal). We expect that structural stigma regarding sexual orientation will be associated with smaller hippocampal volume and heightened amygdala reactivity to threat cues among sexual minorities at future time points in ABCD data collection (around age 12-13 years). In addition, identities continue to form during adolescence and structural stigma experiences accumulate during this developmental period. Consequently, we expect the association between structural stigma, smaller hippocampal volume, and greater amygdala reactivity to threat to become stronger over time for all four groups (i.e., the effect size will increase in the longitudinal assessments).   

Hypothesis #3. Structural forms of stigma will not be related to hippocampal volume or amygdala reactivity to threat, either at baseline or longitudinally, among the non-stigmatized comparison groups: boys, heterosexuals, and non-Hispanic Whites. This analysis will serve as a negative control approach (Lipsitch, Tchetgen, & Cohen, 2010), in that we test whether there is an association among groups where we would not theoretically expect it.

registration_responses.q17.question:
Independent Variables:
The exposure variables of interest will be state-level structural stigma, relevant to the minority subgroup of interest in each stratified analysis. These are sexual minorities, girls, Latinx, and Black participants. Each of these exposures was compiled from previously-validated sources and then modeled as indicators in a factor analysis, with the final factor score determining the structural stigma score for each state for each domain of stigma. Variable selection and model specification are described here. With the exception of anti-immigrant sentiment (which had a limited inventory of possible indicators), we restricted all indicators to those that had measures for all 50 states and Washington, D.C. The rationale for including all 50 states was to contextualize the factor scores relative to national climate; after models were run using all 50 states, only the states containing ABCD sites will be selected from the larger exposure dataset. See Table 1 for description of final variables. 
Structural Stigma Related to Sex/Gender
Variable selection from General Social Survey 
We selected from eight questions in the General Social Survey (GSS) that had been previously validated as measures of state-level sexism and had been shown to be relatively stable over time (Charles, Guryan, & Pan, 2009; Homan, 2019). These asked about attitudes towards women’s and women’s stereotypical gender roles. Of these, four had been routinely assessed in recent years and were considered for inclusion in the final model.

Variable selection from ANES
We selected from four items in the American National Elections Studies (ANES) Time-Series Survey that assessed attitudes towards stereotypical gender roles and efforts to address women’s rights, gender equality, and gender discrimination.  

Variable selection from Project Implicit
We selected from 16 items included across two Project Implicit Modules assessing sexism within the contexts of careers and science.  The two modules included: 1) The Gender-Career IAT Module; and 2) The Gender-Science IAT Module.  We selected 3 items from The Gender-Career IAT module. These items included an Implicit Association Test assessing the implicit link between gender and a career vs family focus, and two explicit attitude items which assessed gender norms in relation to family and career.  We selected 12 items from the Gender-Science IAT module.  These 12 items included one Implicit Association Test assessing the implicit link between gender and a science vs liberal arts educational focus, and 11 explicit items measuring attitudes, beliefs, and expectations about gendered participation in science, reasons for gender disparities among faculty members in higher education, and gendered performance in STEM fields.
Finally, we examined a series of other state-level measures of sexism based off two seminal papers on structural sexism. These included economic (i.e. labor force participation; earnings; living below poverty line); political (representation; voting rates); autonomy (educational attainment; business ownership; health access; living in poverty); and reproductive (legal and policy protections) indicators. All of these indicators were taken from the McLaughlin et al 2011 and Homan 2019 papers. We used the same sources as those articles to find these state-level data.
Structural racism

Variable selection from GSS
We selected from questions in the General Social Survey that were associated with the subject matter “Blacks” or “race.” Among these, 11 measures were assessed in recent years and queried by respondents in all 50 states plus D.C. 

Variable selection from ANES
We selected from four items included in the American National Elections Studies (ANES) Time-Series Survey that assessed general attitudes towards African Americans, the impact of discrimination on the lives of African Americans, challenges overcoming prejudice, and endorsement of stereotypes.  

Variable selection from Project Implicit
We selected from twenty-five items included in the Project Implicit Race IAT module.  These items included an Implicit Association Test that assessed the implicit positive preference for white versus black faces and twenty-four items that assessed explicit attitudes towards African Americans and endorsement of stereotypes.

We additionally considered the following Black-White disparities as measures of structural racism: Black-White disparities in voter registration, voter turnout, state elected officials, the civilian labor force, employment, employment in executive/managerial positions, professional specialty, college attainment, incarceration, political disenfranchisement, and death sentencing. These have been implicated with racial disparities in cardiovascular outcomes.  We ultimately did not include any of these in our final model as data were unavailable for all 50 states.

Structural stigma related to sexual orientation 
We selected eight variables reflective of sexual minority structural stigma: 1) An index of state laws and policies related to sexual orientation legislated as of 2017. Data were obtained from the Movement Advancement Project; 2) Explicit attitudes held towards homosexuality and the legality of same-sex marriage. Data were obtained from a Pew Research Center for the People & the Press Polls conducted in 2017; 3) Explicit policy-specific support towards laws and policies that impact the rights of LGB people and same-sex couples. Data were obtained from Lax and Phillips (2009), who aggregated results from 41 randomly sampled national public opinion polls, consisting of approximately 80,000 respondents, and conducted from 1999 through 2008 by various organizations (e.g., Gallup, Pew); 4) Implicit attitudes held towards sexual minorities, which were obtained from Project Implicit through which participants voluntarily completed the sexuality version of the Implicit Association Test; 5) A weighted proportion of openly LGBTQ elected government officials. Data were obtained from the Victory Institute’s Out for America interactive map; 6) The proportion of public high schools with Gay-Straight Alliances (GSAs).  Data on GSAs were obtained from the 2016 CDC School Health Profiles; 7) Estimated percentage of LGBT adults living in each state and 8) the estimated density of same-sex couples living in each state.  These data were obtained from the Williams Institute at the UCLA School of Law.


Structural stigma related to Latinx ethnicity
For this domain, very few measures were available for all 50 states plus Washington, D.C., so we excluded Washington, D.C., from the factor analysis. We chose from measures that included explicit attitudinal questions regarding Latinx populations as well as measures related to immigration. As mentioned above, we used measures related to immigration attitudes based on previous findings that immigration policies and attitudes affect the mental health of Latinx respondents regardless of nativity status (e.g., Hatzenbuehler et al., 2017) because of a) the conflation of immigration with Latinx ethnicity in the US, b) the mixed status nature of many Latinx households, and c) the concealability of immigration status, which makes people targets regardless of whether they are a citizen.

Variable selection from GSS
From the General Social Survey, all measures related to the subject “Hispanic” or that appeared using a search for “immigrant” or “immigration” were considered. This consisted of 23 variables; ultimately, only a single one was queried in recent years and had data available for all 50 states. 

Variable selection from ANES
We selected from three items included in the American National Elections Studies (ANES) Times-Series Survey that assessed general attitudes towards Hispanics, attitudes towards illegal immigrants, and endorsement of stereotypes. 

A series of state-level anti-immigrant measures were considered: these were made available by Wake Forest University School of Medicine and provided directly by the project lead, Scott Rhodes. These included state-level policies that were protective or discriminatory towards immigrants; the variable ultimately considered for inclusion from these measures was a sum score for each state representing how supportive or discriminatory the overall laws were, ranging from a score of -6 to +5. These were reverse-coded so that more discriminatory laws had a higher value.

Data cleaning
All measures were coded such that higher levels corresponded to higher values of structural stigma. Measures were standardized to their average response value for all respondents, regardless of state of residence, and aggregated to the state level so that every state’s measure was the mean of the standardized individual response for respondents residing in that state. The exception was state-level variables, which were already measured at the state level and thus were not aggregated or standardized further. Measures met inclusion criteria for model selection if residents of every state and Washington, D.C., were represented in the data. The exception is anti-immigrant sentiment, which heavily relied on measures of state policies; thus, data from Washington, D.C., was not non-existent and so was not included in the models. 
While the indicators often represented different survey years (e.g., General Social Survey questions ranged from the 1970’s to present day), we aggregated all responses to the state level regardless of year queried. Averaging the responses in this way allowed for all states to have a sizable number of representative respondents, regardless of sampling variation from year to year. Structural sexism and structural racism in particular have been shown to decline nationally over time, but the relative stigma levels of individual states (i.e., rankings relative to other states) have remained stable despite national declines overall, so aggregating across multiple years is a commonly accepted technique for assessing structural stigma (Charles et al., 2009; Homan, 2019; McKetta et al., 2017).

Indicator selection into final model
We then created a factor score for each state for each measure by using exploratory factor analysis with a factor loading cut off of 0.40; we reran the factor analysis iteratively and excluded variables until all items in the factor analysis met the 0.40 threshold (n=18 for structural stigma related to sex/gender, n=29 for structural stigma related to race, n=8 for structural stigma related to sexual orientation, and n=4 for structural stigma related to Latinx ethnicity). We performed this analysis using PROC FACTOR in SAS 9.4, with the prior communality estimate fixed at squared multiple correlations with all other variables and oblimin rotation. We considered both a 1-factor and 2-factor solution but chose the 1-factor solution after deeming the 2-factor solution uninterpretable. The variables selected for the final analysis based on the 0.40 loading threshold are included in the attached table. 

Perceived discrimination will be operationalized in two ways: dichotomously and continuously.  

Dichotomous outcomes will be defined as follows:  
Yes on dim_yesno_q1 for race
Yes on dim_yesno_q1 OR dim_yesno_q2 for Latinx ethnicity
Yes on dim_yesno_q3 for sexual orientation

Continuous outcomes will be defined as follows:
The average of dim_matrix_q1 to dim_matrix_q7 for Latinx ethnicity
The average of dim_matrix_q5 to dim_matrix_q7 for race, gender, and sexual orientation

Dependent Variables:
bilateral hippocampal volume, calculated by taking the mean volume across the right and left hemispheres (smri_vol_scs_hpuslh, smri_vol_scs_hpusrh), 
amygdala activation to negative vs. neutral faces, separately for right and left amygdala (tfmri_nback_all_224, tfmri_nback_all_238)

Covariates:
age, sex at birth, marital status of household, household income, race, and ethnicity, total intracranial volume
registration_responses.q19.question: Analyses will be conducted using generalized mixed-effects models. Subjects are nested within family (sibs) and families nested within site. Implemented using gamm4 function in R.

attributes.title: Tolerance for wealth and income inequality: Compassion and ‘Self Love’

q1.value: Tolerance for wealth and income inequality: Compassion and ‘Self-love’

q3.value:
Economic inequality, or the unequal distribution of income, wealth, property and financial assets, is a long-standing societal issue affecting nations worldwide and an important topic of interest in the social sciences.

Recent experimental research showed that high social mobility beliefs promote acceptance and tolerance for inequality, and exposure to low mobility beliefs reduces willingness to defend the status quo inequality (Shariff et al., 2016; Day & Fiske, 2017). Driven by this evidence, we wanted to further explore tolerance for inequality and understand what makes people more or less open to supporting or opposing economic equality.

This study was designed to find out whether tolerance for income and wealth inequality is associated with psychological orientations, emotions, and behavioral tendencies suggested by the non-empirical theories of Jean Jacques Rousseau in the Discourse on the Origins and Basis of Inequality Among Men (1755). With his main argument being that humans have evolved away from compassion and towards ‘self-love' (translated from “amour-propre”), Rousseau claimed that inequality in society stems from individuals’ self-interest, egoism, envy, vanity, contempt, pride, desire for accumulation, and need to compare and compete with others.

Thus, in this research study we will look at Rousseau’s theories from an empirical viewpoint and test whether certain motivations, personality traits, social behaviors, and emotional dispositions are associated with greater or lesser concern about inequality. In addition to investigating individuals’ attitudes towards economic inequality in a Canadian population sample, this study adds to existing literature by providing a novel perspective on the behaviors, emotions and motivations at play in the tolerance and maintenance of economic inequality. 

Correlational evidence related to our predictions may open avenues for further research using experimental designs in a controlled environment.

References: 

Day, M. V., & Fiske, S. T. (2017). Movin’ on up? How perceptions of social mobility affect our willingness to defend the system. Social Psychological and Personality Science, 8(3), 267-273. DOI:10.1177/1948550616678454. 
Rousseau J.,J. (1755). Discourse on the Origins and Foundations of Inequality Among Men. The discourses and other early political writings, translated by V. Gourevitch. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. Available from: https://oll.libertyfund.org/titles/rousseau-the-social-contract-and-discourses.
Shariff, A. F., Wiwad, D., & Aknin, L. B. (2016). Income mobility breeds tolerance for income inequality. Perspectives on Psychological Science, 11(3), 373–380. DOI:10.1177/1745691616635596

q4.value:
Prior research on correlates of tolerance toward inequality has sometimes produced effects in the range of r=.20 (Shariff et al., 2016), so we anticipate similar effect sizes here. 

H1: Participants who score highly on compassion will report lower tolerance for economic inequality (TEI). 
H2: Participants who score highly on extrinsic motivation (aspirations of wealth, image and fame) will report higher tolerance for economic inequality (TEI).
H3: Participants who score highly on envy will report higher tolerance for economic inequality (TEI).
H4: Participants who score highly on pride will report higher tolerance for economic inequality (TEI).
H5: Participants who score highly on contempt will report higher tolerance for economic inequality (TEI).
H6: Participants who score highly on self-interest will report higher tolerance for economic inequality (TEI).
H7: Participants who score highly on narcissism will report higher tolerance for economic inequality (TEI).

q5.value: Observational Study - Data is collected from study subjects that are not randomly assigned to a treatment. This includes surveys, “natural experiments,” and regression discontinuity designs.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: The proposed study is a correlational survey design. The researchers will measure different behavioral tendencies, emotional dispositions and motivational variables, along with individuals’ tolerance for economic inequality to find potential positive or negative associations.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value:
Participants: 

Participants must be at least 18 years of age and be living in Canada to participate. Anyone fitting in these criteria will be eligible to participate in this study. Douglas College students, faculty and staff will all be welcome to participate, as well as anyone from the general population. All participants will be self-selected to participate in this study (volunteer participants).

Participants must be living in Canada because the questions relating to attitudes towards economic inequality are specifically targeting Canadian society; thus, participants must be living in this country to be able to accurately answer those questions.

Recruitment and survey administration: 

The survey will be designed and administered online using Qualtrics. Douglas College students will be recruited to participate through the Douglas College students research participation system (SONA) directing them to the qualtrics survey. Students whose classes are not part of the research pool, faculty, staff, and anyone from the general population may also enter the survey through a Qualtrics link provided via advertisements on Douglas College campuses and on social media. 

Data collection: 

Once participants enter the Qualtrics survey, an informed consent form will appear on their screen explaining the study, their right to withdraw, the ways in which their answers will be used, and the benefits of their participation. After consent has been given, they will proceed to a survey containing a series of questions from different psychological assessments of self-interest, envy, pride, compassion, contempt, narcissism, and extrinsic aspirations (wealth, fame and image). Individuals will also be asked to answer six questions on their attitudes towards economic inequality, and a series of demographic questions, which will include their age, ethnic background, income level and social class. There will also be four questions designed to assess whether participants are careful in answering the survey.

Upon completion of the survey, a debriefing form will be provided to further explain the purpose of the study, significance, contact information of researchers, and further reading on the psychological effects of economic inequality. All participants will be able to withdraw or opt-out from the study at any point without penalty.  

Compensation: 

Participants from the Douglas College courses whose instructor offers course credit, will receive a bonus course credit (1%) upon completion of the study. 

Participants not from the Douglas College research participation pool system (SONA) will have the opportunity to enter a raffle at the end of the study for a chance to win either a $20, a $50, or a $100 electronic Amazon gift card redeemable at Amazon.ca. The winners will be sent an email notification and a request for a confirmation.

q13.value: Up to 500 participants will participate in this study. The sample will be made of Douglas College students and individuals from the general population. Participants must be at least 18 years of age and be living in Canada to participate. All participants will be self-selected to participate in this study (volunteer participants).

q14.value:
Sample size calculation (using G* Power) showed that for a 2-tail test with an effect size of r=0.2 and 90% statistical power and an alpha of .01, a sample of 361 is needed. In order to achieve a complete set of 361 participants’ data, a sample of 500 individuals would be ideal. This will allow rigorous data cleaning, so we retain for data analyses, only the participants who carefully responded.

Limited funds and time restrict the number of participants of participants in this study.

q15.value:
We will stop collecting data when any of the following occur: 
•	500 participants have completed the questionnaire.
•	6 weeks have passed after the start of the study.
•	March 15st 2020.

question.value: No variables will be manipulated.

The key variables in this study are the Tolerance for income inequality and for wealth inequality, which will be measured using a 3-item attitudes towards income inequality scale adapted to focus on Canada and 3 very similar items focused on wealth inequality (IWIA; adapted from Shariff, Wiwad, & Aknin, 2016). 

The other variables will be measured with:

Scale Preparation:

• Cronbach’s Alpha will be calculated for each scale.
• Scale scores will be calculated by averaging the scores of the relevant items, after reversing items scores where needed: Tolerance for wealth inequality, tolerance for income inequality, extrinsic motivation subscales (wealth aspirations, fame aspirations, and image aspirations), dispositional compassion, dispositional pride, benign envy, dispositional contempt, self-interest, and narcissism. 
• If the correlation between tolerance for wealth inequality and income inequality exceeds r=.80 and the combined scale has a Cronbach’s Alpha higher than the average of the separate Cronbach’s Alphas, then the two scales will be collapsed. 

Descriptive Statistics:

• Means and standard deviations of all major variables will be calculated. 
• A table or correlations will be produced showing correlations among the variables expected to be associated with tolerance for inequality.

Control Variables:

Control variables considered include age, and gender. Each will be tested in multiple regression with the tolerance variable(s), and each producing a significant beta will be controlled for in the following substantive analyses. 

Hypothesis Testing:

Substantive analyses of the hypotheses will be conducted using partial correlations of the expected correlates with the tolerance variable(s).

q21.value: We will use the standard p- value, p <.05, for all analyses. P values, confidence intervals, and effect sizes will be reported. We will use two-tailed tests.

q22.value:
• Participants who fail at least two careful responding checks will removed from the data (e.g., “To show that you are reading carefully, please select ‘strongly agree’ in response to this statement”).
• Scale scores more than 3.29 SDs above or below the mean will be removed.
• Participants missing any of the calculated scale scores will be removed (with the exception of demographic data) unless that moves the number of participants below 361 (the sample size required according to the power analysis).

q23.value: Participants missing any of the calculated scale scores will be removed (with the exemption of demographic data) and will not be included in data analysis unless that moves the number of participants below 361 (the sample size required according to the power analysis).

q24.value: Gender, age, socioeconomic status, years of residence, perceived social class, and vertical individualism will be examined separately as variables to determine potential correlates for tolerance for economic inequality We will also analyze the relationship between tolerance for inequality and dispositional and contextual explanations of inequality.

registration_responses.q1: Tolerance for wealth and income inequality: Compassion and ‘Self-love’
registration_responses.q3:
Economic inequality, or the unequal distribution of income, wealth, property and financial assets, is a long-standing societal issue affecting nations worldwide and an important topic of interest in the social sciences.

Recent experimental research showed that high social mobility beliefs promote acceptance and tolerance for inequality, and exposure to low mobility beliefs reduces willingness to defend the status quo inequality (Shariff et al., 2016; Day & Fiske, 2017). Driven by this evidence, we wanted to further explore tolerance for inequality and understand what makes people more or less open to supporting or opposing economic equality.

This study was designed to find out whether tolerance for income and wealth inequality is associated with psychological orientations, emotions, and behavioral tendencies suggested by the non-empirical theories of Jean Jacques Rousseau in the Discourse on the Origins and Basis of Inequality Among Men (1755). With his main argument being that humans have evolved away from compassion and towards ‘self-love' (translated from “amour-propre”), Rousseau claimed that inequality in society stems from individuals’ self-interest, egoism, envy, vanity, contempt, pride, desire for accumulation, and need to compare and compete with others.

Thus, in this research study we will look at Rousseau’s theories from an empirical viewpoint and test whether certain motivations, personality traits, social behaviors, and emotional dispositions are associated with greater or lesser concern about inequality. In addition to investigating individuals’ attitudes towards economic inequality in a Canadian population sample, this study adds to existing literature by providing a novel perspective on the behaviors, emotions and motivations at play in the tolerance and maintenance of economic inequality. 

Correlational evidence related to our predictions may open avenues for further research using experimental designs in a controlled environment.

References: 

Day, M. V., & Fiske, S. T. (2017). Movin’ on up? How perceptions of social mobility affect our willingness to defend the system. Social Psychological and Personality Science, 8(3), 267-273. DOI:10.1177/1948550616678454. 
Rousseau J.,J. (1755). Discourse on the Origins and Foundations of Inequality Among Men. The discourses and other early political writings, translated by V. Gourevitch. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press. Available from: https://oll.libertyfund.org/titles/rousseau-the-social-contract-and-discourses.
Shariff, A. F., Wiwad, D., & Aknin, L. B. (2016). Income mobility breeds tolerance for income inequality. Perspectives on Psychological Science, 11(3), 373–380. DOI:10.1177/1745691616635596
registration_responses.q4:
Prior research on correlates of tolerance toward inequality has sometimes produced effects in the range of r=.20 (Shariff et al., 2016), so we anticipate similar effect sizes here. 

H1: Participants who score highly on compassion will report lower tolerance for economic inequality (TEI). 
H2: Participants who score highly on extrinsic motivation (aspirations of wealth, image and fame) will report higher tolerance for economic inequality (TEI).
H3: Participants who score highly on envy will report higher tolerance for economic inequality (TEI).
H4: Participants who score highly on pride will report higher tolerance for economic inequality (TEI).
H5: Participants who score highly on contempt will report higher tolerance for economic inequality (TEI).
H6: Participants who score highly on self-interest will report higher tolerance for economic inequality (TEI).
H7: Participants who score highly on narcissism will report higher tolerance for economic inequality (TEI).

Sample size calculation (using G* Power) showed that for a 2-tail test with an effect size of r=0.2 and 90% statistical power and an alpha of .01, a sample of 361 is needed. In order to achieve a complete set of 361 participants’ data, a sample of 500 individuals would be ideal. This will allow rigorous data cleaning, so we retain for data analyses, only the participants who carefully responded.

Limited funds and time restrict the number of participants of participants in this study.

The researchers will measure different behavioral tendencies, emotional dispositions and motivational variables, along with individuals’ tolerance for economic inequality to find potential positive or negative associations.
registration_responses.q12.question:
Participants: 

Participants must be at least 18 years of age and be living in Canada to participate. Anyone fitting in these criteria will be eligible to participate in this study. Douglas College students, faculty and staff will all be welcome to participate, as well as anyone from the general population. All participants will be self-selected to participate in this study (volunteer participants).

Participants must be living in Canada because the questions relating to attitudes towards economic inequality are specifically targeting Canadian society; thus, participants must be living in this country to be able to accurately answer those questions.

Recruitment and survey administration: 

The survey will be designed and administered online using Qualtrics. Douglas College students will be recruited to participate through the Douglas College students research participation system (SONA) directing them to the qualtrics survey. Students whose classes are not part of the research pool, faculty, staff, and anyone from the general population may also enter the survey through a Qualtrics link provided via advertisements on Douglas College campuses and on social media. 

Data collection: 

Once participants enter the Qualtrics survey, an informed consent form will appear on their screen explaining the study, their right to withdraw, the ways in which their answers will be used, and the benefits of their participation. After consent has been given, they will proceed to a survey containing a series of questions from different psychological assessments of self-interest, envy, pride, compassion, contempt, narcissism, and extrinsic aspirations (wealth, fame and image). Individuals will also be asked to answer six questions on their attitudes towards economic inequality, and a series of demographic questions, which will include their age, ethnic background, income level and social class. There will also be four questions designed to assess whether participants are careful in answering the survey.

Upon completion of the survey, a debriefing form will be provided to further explain the purpose of the study, significance, contact information of researchers, and further reading on the psychological effects of economic inequality. All participants will be able to withdraw or opt-out from the study at any point without penalty.  

Compensation: 

Participants from the Douglas College courses whose instructor offers course credit, will receive a bonus course credit (1%) upon completion of the study. 

Participants not from the Douglas College research participation pool system (SONA) will have the opportunity to enter a raffle at the end of the study for a chance to win either a $20, a $50, or a $100 electronic Amazon gift card redeemable at Amazon.ca. The winners will be sent an email notification and a request for a confirmation.
