attributes.title: Mistakes were repeated: Episodic retrieval of erroneous responses

q1.value: Mistakes were made: Episodic retrieval of erroneous responses

q3.value: In this study we investigate processes of stimulus-response binding and retrieval for erroneous responses. Are mistakes stored and retrieved from memory, like correct responses, leading to a perpetuation of erroneous behaviour? Or do people take into account that an error was made, storing and retrieving only correct or corrected responses? Or, are there other mechanisms at play? This experiment is designed to assess SR binding and retrieval effects in a sequential prime/probe design using a colour classification task, with an orthogonal variation of response relation (colour repetition vs. change) and stimulus relation (word repetition vs. change). We compare SR binding and retrieval for correct responses and for errors that occur under time pressure (chance errors) in a student sample (n=60).

q4.value:
1) We predict standard SR binding effects following accurate responses in the prime trials, i.e. facilitation effects of stimulus repetition in reaction time and accuracy for probe trials with response repetition, and interference effects for response changes.

2) For trials following an error in the prime, we test the following theories:
2a) No Retrieval after error (“success-based retrieval”): reflected by a null effect owing to previous incorrect response being not stored in episodic memory since this theory predicts that only successful information is stored.
2b) Dual Process account: reflected by a null effect owing to both, executed erroneous response and non-executed correct response being recalled. This leads to both processes cancelling each other out, explaining the null effect. To distinguish this account from the success-based retrieval account, we predict that particularly in trials where neither the erroneous nor the correct response is relevant to the stimulus that is presented in the probe (a third colour), we expect to see higher interference effects since both responses are recalled, and their irrelevance to the presented stimulus should lead to higher reaction times.
2c) Only the executed response is retrieved in all instances, regardless of whether it is correct or incorrect (unconditional response retrieval): reflected by facilitation for probe trials where response repetition is the correct response (colour repetition), and interference for trials where the colour changes in the probe, regardless of prime status (correct vs. error).
2d) Only the rule is retrieved in all instances (target retrieval account): reflected by facilitation for colour repetitions in the probe, and interference for colour change in the probe, regardless of prime status (correct vs. error).

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: Within subjects design with 3 nested factors: Distractor relation (word repetition vs. word change), prime status (correct response vs. error), response relation (repetition vs. change for correct prime responses; repetition of executed erroneous response vs. repetition of  to-be-executed response vs. response change), resulting in a 2 x 2 design within the correct prime response condition, and a 2 x 3 design within the erroneous prime response condition.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Primarily, students of Friedrich Schiller University, Jena will be recruited for participation in this study. Participants will be recruited using posters and flyers displayed across the university campus, as well as through personal contacts. Participants are paid at the rate of Eur 8 per hour of their time, along with an additional bar of chocolate at the end of the experiment to incentivise completing the task by abiding to all the instructions. There are no strict eligibility criteria. We will try to balance participants for age and gender. Roughly, we aim to complete data collection in 2 weeks, followed by 6-8 weeks on data analysis and interpretation. Following this, the results will be used for dissemination and science communication.

q13.value: For a moderate effect size, a sample size of 56 would be needed according to an a-priori power-analysis done with G*Power (Version 3.1.9.4).

q14.value: We aim to test roughly 60 participants, taking into consideration outliers and unusable data.

question.value:
We will be studying the following variables:
Distractor relation: distractor repetition vs. distractor change
Prime response status: correct response in the prime vs. erroneous response in the prime
Response relation: response repetition vs. response change within the correct prime response condition; repetition of the executed response vs. repetition of the to-be-executed response vs. different response in the incorrect prime response condition.

We aim to measure reaction time and accuracy. More precisely, we are interested in error rate, and how errors impact performance.
For this, we will be using a sequential prime-probe design, and evaluating participants' performance (RT and error rate) on probe trials after they made an error in the prime compared to their performance (RT and error rate) after a correct response on the prime.
Repeated measures ANOVAs will be calculated for mean reaction times, mean error rates, and mean IES (Inverse Efficiency Score [IES=RT/ACC] for each condition of the within subjects design.

Since all hypotheses rest on error rates and reaction times, the same statistical analyses will be used:
Repeated measures ANOVAs for mean reaction times, mean error rates and mean IES (Inverse Efficiency Score), with repeated measures on the three within subjects factors of the design.

q21.value: We will use the standard p<.05 criteria for determining if the ANOVA and the post hoc test suggest that the results are significantly different from those expected if the null hypotheses were correct.

q22.value: Participants with extreme error rates indicating random responding on most of the trials will be rejected from analyses. For RT analyses, we will exclude outlier responses according to Tukey’s outlier criterion (1,5 interquartile ranges above the third quartile).

q23.value: If the participant terminates the experiment before completion, this will be rejected as missing data. Other factors like being under the influence of substances, or random responding will also lead to exclusion of data.

q25.value: This is a follow-up study on an experiment recently conducted at the Department of General Psychology, 2 in the Institute for Psychology, Jena. While still a colour categorisation task, the experiment procedure has been altered to enhance the detection of a retrieval effect (if present). Precisely, we have modified the procedure of stimulus presentation by adding a presentation of the distractor (word) in white before the it changes to one of the three target colours, to help detect a retrieval effect. The duration of the inter-stimulus interval has also been increased to better define distinct episodes, since the previous experiment had shorter gaps between stimuli. The rest of the procedure as well as the core question, however, remain the same - what is stored and retrieved after an error is made?

Response relation: response repetition vs. response change within the correct prime response condition; repetition of the executed response vs. repetition of the to-be-executed response vs. different response in the incorrect prime response condition.
registration_responses.q17.question:
We aim to measure reaction time and accuracy. More precisely, we are interested in error rate, and how errors impact performance.
For this, we will be using a sequential prime-probe design, and evaluating participants' performance (RT and error rate) on probe trials after they made an error in the prime compared to their performance (RT and error rate) after a correct response on the prime.
registration_responses.q18.question: Repeated measures ANOVAs will be calculated for mean reaction times, mean error rates, and mean IES (Inverse Efficiency Score [IES=RT/ACC] for each condition of the within subjects design.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Since all hypotheses rest on error rates and reaction times, the same statistical analyses will be used:
Repeated measures ANOVAs for mean reaction times, mean error rates and mean IES (Inverse Efficiency Score), with repeated measures on the three within subjects factors of the design.

attributes.title: A reason-based account of context effects

q1.value: A reason-based account of the attraction effect

q2.value: Neo Poon, Andrea Isoni, Ashley Luckman, Timothy L Mullett

q3.value:
This project aims to examine the psychological process behind the so-called "attraction effect" in behavioural science by exploring the reason structure of decision makers. The attraction effect refers to the observed change in preferences between two options which depends on the attribute values of an asymmetrically dominated third option (Huber, Payne, and Puto, 1982). In particular preferences usually shift towards the dominating option.

The main motivation for considering a reason-based account for this effect comes from Query Theory (Johnson, Häubl, and Keinan, 2007). Query Theory suggests that individuals make decisions by generating reasons, with reasons favouring the chosen option generated both earlier in the decision-making process and in greater quantity. Despite its simplicity and the ability to explain a range of behavioural phenomena such as the default effect (Dinner, Johnson, Goldstein, and Liu, 2011), attribute framing (Hardisty, Johnson, and Weber, 2010), and asymmetric discounting in intertemporal choices (Weber et al., 2007), Query Theory has not yet been tested beyond simple binary choices, such as the three-alternative choice structure needed to demonstrate the attraction effect. In their standard forms, its two key measures (the order and quantity scores) cannot be applied directly to multi-alternative choices.

The project aims to extend this reason-based process model and investigate the extent to which its mechanisms can explain the attraction effect.

q4.value:
Consider a ternary choice (e.g. A vs B vs C) with two attributes (e.g. 1 and 2). Assume that option A has a high value on attribute 1 and a low value on attribute 2, option B has a low value on attribute 1 and a high value on attribute 2, while option C is similar to option A but both of its attribute values are slightly lower than those of option A.

Here, option A is the dominating option and is usually termed the "target", option B is the non-dominated option and is termed the "competitor", while option C is asymmetrically dominated by option A and is termed the "decoy".

The above example is an illustration of the attraction effect. In our experiment the attribute values of the decoy option C change between conditions, such that either option A or option B will become the target.

The key hypotheses are as follow.

H1: The choice share of an option will be higher when it is the target than when it is not 

As the decoy is inferior to the target on all attributes, we expect that:

H2: The decoy option will not be chosen

Query Theory suggests that:

H3: Reasons in favour of the chosen option will be generated in greater quantity

H4: Reasons in favour of the chosen option will be generated earlier

From H1, H3, and H4, we further predict:

H5: Reasons in favour of an option will be generated in greater quantity when it is the target than when it is not 

H6: Reasons in favour of an option will be generated earlier when it is the target than when it is not 

Lastly, based on previous studies (e.g. Adjerid et al., 2016), we predict that the order of the experimental procedures does not change choices, the quantity of reasons supporting each option, or the order of reasons supporting each option, therefore scenario (Reason First vs Choice First) will have no effects. See the "Study design" section for details.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value:
An online experiment will be carried out for this study.

Before the beginning the experiment, the webpage will identify whether the participant is using a mobile device to access the task. If they are, they will be informed that the experiment will not run appropriately on a mobile device. Participants will then be shown the consent form and the instruction page.

Main stages: Choice, Aspect Listing, Aspect Coding, Reason Weighting, and Confidence.

The order of the first two stages (i.e. Choice and Aspect Listing) are randomised. See below for the experimental manipulation "Scenario".

- Choice: Participants will be asked to make one consumer choice with three options. 

- Aspect Listing: Participants will be asked to think of reasons which come to their minds as they are considering the options, and input these reasons one at a time. They will be required to input at least one reason, and the reason listing procedure will be terminated when they decide that they have already inputted all reasons which allow them to make the choice, or when they have inputted 10 reasons, whichever comes first. 

- Aspect Coding: Participants will be asked to code each of their reasons. In this stage, participants will be asked to indicate which of the three options a reason supports. In other words, only positive coding is allowed.

- Reason Weighting: Participants will be asked to weight the importance of each reason. 

- Confidence: Participants will be asked to rate how confident they are in their choice.

Lastly, one attention check question is included at the end of the experiment, and participants will be asked a multiple-choice question about the type of products their choice was about.

The key experimental manipulations involve a 2 (Target: Option A vs Option B) x 2 (Scenario: Reason First vs Choice First) between-subject design.

The two Target conditions are to check whether the attraction effect exists and whether preference can be reversed when the target changes. The two Scenario conditions are included to check whether that the order of the experimental procedures changes decision outcomes, the number of reasons, or the order of reasons. As stated in the "Hypotheses" section, we expect no difference.

q9.value: Complete randomisation which aims for balanced cell sizes. Participants will be assigned to each experimental cell randomly by a computer script.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited through Prolific and will be paid £1 for an expected duration of 5-10 minutes. Only UK residents and native English speakers will be recruited.

q13.value:
A short pilot with 30 participants will first be run to ensure the technical aspects of the experiment work as intended.

During this initial check, no statistical analyses of any kind will be performed and the hypotheses will not be tested. The purpose of this initial test is to ensure that:

(1) Participants can connect to the experiment from Prolific
(2) Participants can complete every stage of the experiment
(3) Participants can return to Prolific after finishing the experiment
(4) The responses of the participants are saved on the server
(5) The researchers can extract participants' responses from the server

Technical changes to the experiment might be made to ensure that the experiment can fulfil the above requirements, but no changes to the experimental design will be performed.

After the pilot, 280 participants will be recruited for the main study.

If no changes are performed after the pilot, responses of all 310 (30 + 280) participants will enter the data analysis stage. If changes are performed, responses from the pilot will be excluded.

q14.value: At least 60 participants per cell are needed to obtain a power of at least 0.9 to detect the effect size shown in previous studies investigating the Query Theory at the standard .05 value of alpha. We decided to recruit at least 70 participants per cell, totalling 280 participants.

question.value: The 2 key manipulated variables are the treatment groups: Target (A vs B) and Scenario (Reason First vs Choice First).

The variables which are directly measured are: Choices, Reasons, Reason Coding, Importance of Reasons, and Confidence.

Reasons and Reason Coding will be combined and used to compute metrics which represent the extent to which reasons in favour of an option are generated earlier and in greater quantity.

The details of the metrics are illustrated in the "Indices" section below.

Two types of metrics will be created: Content scores and Order scores.

Generally, in studies related to Query Theory, a Content score measures the extent to which reasons in favour of an option are generated in greater quantity, while a Order score measures the extent to which reasons in favour of an option are generated earlier.

For binary choices (e.g. A vs B), most previous studies computed exactly two metrics, as shown below:

Content = (n_A - n_B) / N

where Content represents the extent to which reasons supporting A are generated in greater quantity by an participant, n_A is the number of reasons supporting A generated by that participant, n_B is the number of reasons supporting B, and N is the total number of reasons. (Since all previous studies, to our knowledge, used binary choices, reasons opposing an option are coded as reasons supporting the other option.)

Order = 2 * (MR_B - MR_A) / N

where Order represents the extent to which reasons supporting A are generated earlier by an participant, MR_A is the median rank (a smallest rank represents an earlier appearance) of reasons supporting A for that participant, MR_B is the median rank of reasons supporting B, while N is defined above.

An important aspect of our analysis is the generalisation of these metrics to more than two options, and we have decided to compute separate Content and Order score for each option.

Given three options (e.g A vs B vs C):

Content_A = n_A / N

here Content_A is the proportion of reasons supporting A among all reasons generated by a participant, while n_A and N are defined above.

Content_B and Content_C are defined analogously.

Further, Content scores can be defined for the Target, Competitor, and Decoy in each condition. Content_Target, Content_Competitor, and Content_Decoy are defined analogously.

Order_A = MR_A / (N + 1), if n_A is greater than 0
Order_A = N + 1, if n_A = 0
                
here Order_A is the average position of reasons supporting A among all reasons generated by a participant (with smaller value being earlier), while MR_A, n_A, and N are defined above. 

Order_B and Order_C are defined analogously.

Further, Order scores can be defined for the Target, Competitor, and Decoy in each condition. Order_Target, Order_Competitor, and Order_Decoy are defined analogously.

Since this study extends the Query Theory to a new domain and the statistical tests will rely on new metrics, the analysis will be inevitably exploratory in nature. Nevertheless, a number of statistical models are illustrated below and will guide hypothesis testing.

In previous studies, for binary choices, the main analyses investigated the effects of the experimental manipulations on choice, the effects of the experimental manipulations on the Content score, and the effects of the experimental manipulations on the Order score separately.

Some studies (e.g. Dinner et al., 2011) further tested for mediations. For instance, Choice can be regressed on Content and experimental condition dummy variables. If the effects of the dummy variables on Choice reduce or are eliminated when Content is added to the model, it can be inferred that Content mediates the effect of the experimental condition on Choice (Baron and Kenny, 1986). Whether Order mediates the effect of the experimental condition on Choice can be tested similarly.

In our analyses, for H1 (the choice hypothesis), we will run a logistic regression model to test the choice share of the target, under the assumption that no or very few participants will choose the decoy, and therefore choices are practically binary. (Here, for the sake of simplicity, we use "~" to represent "regressed on".)

Choice (Target vs Non-target) ~ Target (A vs B) + Scenario (Reason First vs Choice First) 

The intercept of this model will tell us whether the target is more likely to be chosen and tests H1 directly.

If a noticeable proportion of participants choosing the decoy (here defined as greater than 10% in each cell), we will use a multinomial model to test the choice shares of each option. See the "Exploratory analysis" section.

For H3 and H4, since we have decided to compute separate Order and Content scores for each option (see the "Indices" section), we will run the following logistic regression models using the two types of metrics:

Choice (A vs B) ~ (Content_A - Content_B) + Scenario (Reason First vs Choice First) + (Content_A - Content_B) x Scenario
Choice (A vs B) ~ (Order_A - Order_B) + Scenario (Reason First vs Choice First) + (Order_A - Order_B) x Scenario

For H5 and H6, we will run the following logistic regression models:

Choice (Target vs Non-target) ~ Content_Target + Content_Decoy + Target (A vs B) + Scenario (Reason First vs Choice First) + Content_Target x Target + Content_Decoy x Target 
Choice (Target vs Non-target) ~ Order_Target + Order_Decoy + Target (A vs B) + Scenario (Reason First vs Choice First) + Order_Target x Target + Order_Decoy x Target

q21.value: p-values (alpha = .05) will be used for all statistical models.

q22.value:
1. Participants will be excluded from data analyses if they fail the attention check question (see the "Study design" section)

2. Reasons which are nonsensical will be excluded from data analyses, but other reasons of the same participant will be included. "Nonsensical reasons" are defined as reasons which cannot be understood as English words, for instance random characters or punctuation.

3. Devices used by participants will be logged and participants will be automatically flagged by the script if they completed the experiment using mobile devices despite the warning. The device logs will be checked manually for all flagged participants, and they will be excluded from data analyses if they are flagged correctly.

q23.value: We see no technical possibility for incomplete response sets to be recorded, since participants cannot submit their responses without completing all stages, but if such an event should occur, these participants will be excluded from analysis.

q24.value:
Since the Query Theory metrics are exclusively used to model binary choices and our experiment involves ternary choices, we will also use our data in an exploratory manner.

For instance, alternative forms of the two metrics might be used, word count of reasons and the completion time of the experiment might be analysed. As mentioned above, if a noticeable proportion of participants choosing the decoy (defined as greater than 10% in each cell), we will use a multinomial model to test the choice shares of each option.

We will also investigate whether the confidence measure is related to other measures collected in the experiment.

Lastly, we are interested in whether the number and order of reasons differ between options and Target, therefore we are interested in running the following mixed effect models:

Content ~ Type (A vs B) + Target (A vs B) + Type x Target
Order ~ Type (A vs B) + Target (A vs B) + Type x Target

summary.value: Here we provide a preregistration document for an upcoming high-powered replication and extension of previous studies contained in this project. The document includes an overview of the study, target sample size and sample size rationale, exclusion criteria, variables to be collected, hypotheses to be tested, and analytic strategy.
